I had never received such an abysmal service and was very disappointed - mostly by the way the place handled whatever crisis they were having that day. I'm sure (or hope) that this is just a one off thing, but with all of the other options in the city - I don't see any reason why I'd come back.
author: Alex H.

description:
Great establishment! Came for Brunch and the mimosas were great and continued to flow. Genuine bartenders and servers. The food was great as well. 

Had a chance to play Cards Against Humanity with a few of the workers and it was freaking great!!! Thanks for a great experience!
author: Alfonso B.

description: Great mimosas, grunge music, chill, and best breakfast you will EVER eat in your life!
author: Shanie W.

description:
-Small bar that attracts a mixed crowd
-$1off beers during happy hour 
-Sliders were smaller than expected. The lamb slider was DELICIOUS and was cooked well. The tilapia slider was just ok.
-Trivia night on Mondays around 730ish...be prepared to lose though, definitely some jeopardy-esque individuals that are ready to make you feel like your whole educational career was a joke :( haha
author: Christine G.

description:
The Sycamore is a staple location for Hipsters who like to smoke on the Patio and people that have $8.50 for a Dogfish Head.   Me?  I like to play Trivial Pursuit and drink Tecate Tallboys, because I'm a classy sophisticate.

They do have good food and a very uneven floor that makes all the table shake and slosh.  I can't, in good faith give this place a 5 but sometimes it is. Monday Trivia Nights are to be participated in or steadfastly avoided.

-LS
author: Lee S.

description:
Came here because my brother lives nearby in the Mission and we were looking for a reasonably quick dinner.  I wanted a burger and fries, so I went in and ordered the sliders and the fries as well as three drinks (two beers and one cider) while my girlfriend and brother went to a burrito place nearby (not feeling the burgers as much).  We all met back at the patio in back of The Sycamore and enjoyed our meal until a waiter came and said - "We do not allow food from outside.  Please pit it away."  We were almost done eating, so we figured we'd just finish and then leave.  Less than a minute later, the server was back - "OK, I am doing being a nice guy.  Pack up your food and get out."  That's right; he threw us out of the bar.  We had spent $30+ on beer and sliders, and that didn't matter to The Sycamore's waitstaff.  Won't be coming back here any time soon!

Food was mediocre at best.  Fries were well seasoned and tasty, but only one of the three sliders (the lamb one) had any real flavor to it.  The chicken one was deep fried but tasteless and the fish one was flavorless.  Beer selection was reasonable.  Outside patio was OK except for all the pot smoke (it is the Mission though).  Overall, nothing particularly outstanding about this place, and the rude waitstaff is definitely a downer.
author: Matthew R.C. Z.

description:
I can't believe I haven't reviewed this before. I love this place!

Their sliders are great, brunch, lunch, dinner--you name it. They have great bottomless mimosas. Odwalla juice and champagne. I've seen this place get PACKED before and my friend and I were just sipping on mimosas for 2 hours before our food came (a bit ridiculous). She didn't give us a full order because they ran out of the chicken and waffles (which are AMAZING) and ended up not charging us for it. 

Chicken and waffles. Where to begin...?
Manchengo cheese and prosciutto...and heavenly bourbon maple sauce. It's truly amazing. The chicken is not as amazing, but it complements it well. Also, their benedicts are yummy! I've had the carnitas benedict and that was awesome. Also, lamb burger slide and beef slider are better than the chicken, fish sliders. The lamb one is really flavorful. The chicken and fish ones aren't as special but still delish.

Cool staff, fun board games. Go for brunch!
author: Natalie M.

description:
I've been to this bar a few times now, and every time, the servers are rude and hell. Their beer selection is OK, but nothing special. Their food is barely passable. They don't do table service, so you have to up to the bar. This might be fine, except that if you order more that one drink at a time, they make you go get your buddy to come up and show their ID. Then, while half of your friends are up in the drink line, or showing IDs, or waiting in line for the one bathroom, a busboy will come around and bug you about having all this empty space at your table, and how your group should scooch over so that others can sit. 

It's all frustrating, and nothing about this place makes it worth the hassle. There are hundreds of other bars in the mission. Do yourself a favor, and go to one of those.
author: Dave R.

description: Part of our Eat-a-thon, we went here on a rainy Saturday. Not too crowded, but since we couldn't sit outdoors, we had to find a place inside for 5 of us. It took quite some time to place our orders since there was only one girl taking orders, but we did enjoy our beers (coffee porter, 15 ale) and white wine sangria. The fries were somewhat salty, but chili-peanuts were good. Best part was playing Uno at the table, there are some many board games to choose from! It looks very hip and we'll definitely come again to try the other food items and beers.
author: Sid W.

description:
Decent food, but you really come here for the $12 bottomless mimosas. None of that watery OJ. They use real juice and champagne. 

Brunch entrees that were pretty good:
The country scramble
The carnitos benedictos

Be sure to snag a table early because it gets crowded pretty quickly!!
author: Alice H.

description:
This reminds me of a coffee shop I used to hang out at in San Diego. With floors so sticky you wondered when was the last time they really mopped, like, got all the dregs of spilt beer and coffee and who-knows-what-else out of every dark crevice (and believe me there were lots of those). And you didn't care that the place smelled like warm milk and there were only two bathrooms that everyone shared because you knew that one day you would upgrade to a real, clean, beautiful coffee shop - because, at the time, you were still in college and this was a place that was just slightly more presentable than your own living room filled with random paraphernalia from endlessly rotating roommates (and the omnipresent bong).

I went on a Sunday and waited an hour (after ordering) for my food. The couple next to us waited so long they just left (without eating).

In conclusion: Don't go on a Sunday - even if this is a brunch place?
author: Melissa W.

description:
Came here twice while visiting SF.

Ambience: Place is small and has a hippiesh vibe. They have board games which is pretty cool. They also have a small beer garden in the back.

Drinks: They have an amazing beer selection, some for quite cheap.

Music: There is a jukebox but when we try to play it, it stole our money. The selections are pretty old. But you don't come here for the music.

This is a good chill spot to have a drink.
author: Rosemary V.

description:
Mimosa brunch anyone? 

This is my neighborhood spot! They have great bites and beer. Brunch is delicious and the mimosas are worth the wait. Definitely a small space but they are good at regulating traffic.
author: Akshaya V.

description:
I loved the ambiance of this place, and the food we ordered ranged from not bad to amazing.

However the waitress spent the whole time talking loudly about "all these white people who have never had to really live life" are ruining san francisco (if it's relevant, she was a white lady from colorado).

This is not, in my opinion, the sort of speech to be shouting at the very people who are paying you $70 for a monday brunch.

Know your audience, yo.
author: Mister L.

description:
Beer selection rotates everyday and is very well curated(Berryessa, Bear Republic, Ommegang). They have wine, sangria, and ciders, but no straight liquor or cocktails.

It's a dive bar that feels welcoming at all times whether you're in a larger group or if it's just yourself. The people that regular this place are very genuine and come from all sorts of different backgrounds. 

The food here is phenomenal when I'm just looking for a comforting place to wind down the afternoon in. Usually I order some sliders and fries, but their roast beef is darn tasty.

Brunch crowd brings a different crowd of people, take that for what you will.

Trivia on monday w/ Master Keith is pretty dope.
author: Patrick L.

description: Stick to the drinks and skip the food. Friendly staff is a plus. For drinks, they have bottomless mimosas, 7-8 taps, and a selection of beer bottles with decent prices. Pretty limited seating. The brunch was just ok. Veggie scramble ($14!! Wtf??) had an eggshell in it--this sin is one of those things that make me pretty much write off a brunch place. BF said the sliders were good, especially the chicken one. Wouldn't come back with all the other places in the Mission.
author: Cara R.

description:
Almost, the definition of a hole-in-the-wall. If you blink you might miss Sycamore at the corner of Sycamore and Mission Street.

This place looks like it's been here forever. It's super-casual. Find a table and place your order at the bar. Try one of the many beers on tap. The sliders were great. You can mix and match and get as much or as little as you want.

The pork belly donuts were incredible. I highly recommend them.
author: Ryan L.

description:
Came here for a quick beer stop before jumping on the bart to SFO. Homey petite bar with a sweet little divey patio out back. Great beer selection with decent prices. Had a good time and enjoyed the company of the patrons sitting at our picnic table. 

Super comfy, will return.
author: Tom T.

description:
It's been fully two years since I last came here for the sliders and I've been recommending the pork belly donuts endlessly to friends. I was so glad to come back and they did not disappoint!

~~Bar snacks~~
* Pork Belly Donuts - 4.5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-sycamore-san-francisco?select=Sbru3lcXG8mE3VOGbxKIaw#69068LDPNO_gFxyVWRcv1A
cross-section: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-sycamore-san-francisco?select=Sbru3lcXG8mE3VOGbxKIaw#ScvAOMzGeqqzIV3sEHFvow
(with Maple Makers Mark Glaze - 3 for $4)
Oh man - as good as I remember! It is because of these that I started liking savory + sweet together. There is slightly less donut/breading that I remember, and it's a little bit more fried, not as soft as I remember. But still freaking amazing, still lovely fatty pork.. definitely a must-have here!

~~Mix 'n Match Sliders: $3.50/ea~~
All the sliders have a lovely buttery & soft bun!
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-sycamore-san-francisco?select=Sbru3lcXG8mE3VOGbxKIaw#k6S1sVXIvuUPHytHrQMzoQ
* Lamb burger - 4.5 stars
(Seasoned Ground Lamb, Caramelized Onions, Romesco Aioli and Manchego Cheese)
Amazing, the best of the bunch. Super gamey flavor, a soft and perfect texture.

* Fried Chicken - 4 stars
(Chicken Breast, Fried Crispy with Pickled Red Onion, Slaw and Roasted Garlic Aioli)
Good crispy, yet soft tender meat. Really tasty, of the four sliders we had, 2nd only to the lamb!

* Beer Battered Catfish - 3 stars
(with Sriracha Aioli and House- Made Pickles)
A little too much batter and not enough meat - and the flavor was a little bland.

* BLT Slider - 3 stars
(Bacon, Butter Lettuce, Heirloom Tomatoes and Smoked Paprika Aioli)
My friend loved this, but I found it underwhelming. I guess if you love BLTs in general, this is a good one to have, but to me it's just really not impressive and so little meat compared to the other sliders!

~~Sandwiches~~
* Sycamore's Famous Roast Beef ($8) - 3.5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-sycamore-san-francisco?select=Sbru3lcXG8mE3VOGbxKIaw#69068LDPNO_gFxyVWRcv1A
A solid sandwich, meat a little tough but still tasty. The sauce is more on the tangy side. and the bun is a good sourdough.
author: Ziyan C.

description: I needed a chill place to hang out after viewing Clarion Alley. I really didn't have any expectations but I came on a Sunday, and they had bottomless mimosas which I was really craving. The staff were all so nice and friendly. The outdoor patio in the back of the restaurant  is perfect for sunny days to chill!
author: Alice O.

description:
This place is definitely pretty much a dive bar. 

I came here to grab a quick beer with a friend I hadn't seen in a long time, and they had a decent selection of drafts. Mostly local which is what I was looking for. We didn't get any food so I can't speak for the food, but the bartender was very friendly and their selection is reasonably well priced.

This place is exceptionally small though, there are maybe four or five tables up front seating about 2 each, a 4-5 seat bar, and then a back patio area.

They have happy hour (I think) so not too shabby all around!
author: Lorrie M.

description:
Ah The Sycamore! I love this place!

Really cool spot in the mission. Art and tagged bathroom give it a very chill vibe. The patio is super cute and the perfect place to grab a beer/play a board game with some friends. Noticed that some nights they also play movies on the wall out on the patio which is fun!

Only wish that they were open later! I understand that they're a gastropub, but it'd be nice if they would at least continue serving alcohol until 2, even if it meant closing the kitchen at 12.
author: Mars S.

description:
BRUNCH RUNDOWN:

Pork belly donuts = little death bombs
Fried chicken slider = dry & tasteless (no, the gobbly gook of mayo-looking gravy did not help)
Pulled pork sandwich = finger-licking enough
Lamb slider = delicious & tasty
Bottomless mimosas = absolutely YES!
author: Peg S.

description:
Places I'll never go again.
The staff was great, so 2 stars. 
It's pretty much the filthy cesspool cousin of that mess formerly known as Lime. 
Yuck.
author: Krismet C.

description:
Came here for brunch with a large group and was completely impressed. The food was great- we all ordered something different and there were no complaints. The chicken and waffles, the carnitas benedicto, and the pork belly donuts were a few of our favorites. 

The bottomless mimosas were refilled frequently. The bloody Mary's were spicy and delicious.
author: Tracy M.

description:
Another of my favorite places of all time.

------------------------------------

Sure bottomless mimosas are great, and theirs is pretty good - it's dry, it's strong, and you'll drink lots - but it's not the only thing.

Be forewarned, there's an $8 minimum food order for those participating in the bottomless mimosas (to keep yo asses sober for longer) because who likes rowdy customers? Not I, nor them.

But omigosh, whatever you'll order will be mouthwateringly amazing: Pork Belly Doughnuts, the Lamb Sliders, the fries, even the salad! Their eggs are sometimes overcooked, but I'll live, cuz it's SO good! The more oily the better. They're super flavorful and served hot.

Indoor and outdoor seating areas are a little cramped, the sun will be in your face no matter where you sit, but who cares? We're all there fora  good time.

They've got chill people working and eating/drinking there. They've got board games, beer, and such good food. and did I mention the food?
author: Eileen ..

description: I know this watering hole is a retro hipster rage, but its limited space and slow service make it a midfield fly ball for this minor leaguer. The bar itself is cramped and on the short side of the room, and there is no room to form a line. I like the chalkboard and the bartenders but only avg for sf.
author: Tom K.

description: Staff and drinks are on point, friendly and knowledgeable, ambiance and backyard are great, menu however no longer carries any significant vegan options (except for sides like fries) so I sadly won't come back for food.  They used to have amazing vegan sliders, what happened!?
author: Charlie S.

description: Zane is very patient and wonderful. He is very attentive to customers needs. Always friendly and welcoming. Will come back because of him.
author: Charilyn Q.

description:
Before I get into my review, I'm just going to rave about the Mimosa Madam. Or Mistress, whatever she prefers. But she was on top of her game. We've done a few bottomless mimosas, and this is the only place where your glass will be half empty and BAM, full again. We lost count of how many we had had, because she was there - and for the whole patio, too. Later we saw her running to pick up more OJ, but damn if this woman doesn't deserve a liver-shaped award and a raise.

Ok, so for the actual review, as I'm the resident Yelper of my group, even though I live the farthest away I'm the one who has to come up with a plan. Using filters, The Sycamore came up as having a patio AND bottomless mimosas, and that was pretty much our only criteria.

My friends and I showed up at the perfect time - around 11 where the place wasn't packed inside or outside yet. We went with patio seating, which is in the back space and on very short picnic tables - my friend who is 6'4" had an interesting time. Fortunately, this is an interesting place.

When you walk in, first thing is pretty much the bar which offers a number of draft beer choices (above the bar is a collection of impressive tap handles), and you order at the bar and eventually they will yell your name when your food is ready - be aware, if you have a common name, you might want to change it up (I go with Mordecai). Then, find some seating and enjoy the wonderfully hipster atmosphere with decorated walls, board games, and interesting people (Not sure if performing troupe or just hipsters).

Seeing pork belly donuts on the menu, had to get those. Got two orders of 3 - pork belly surrounded by fried dough, swimming in syrup. Kind of like sweet and sour pork to give you an idea.

Also got the mix and match sliders: the chicken biscuit and the lamb burger. Both were very tasty (don't forget to grab the sriracha), but actually liked the lamb one better with the Romesco Aioli and Manchego Cheese. 

All of this is excellent hangover cures, though the bottomless mimosas might get you going back.

I would gladly return for the very casual environment, solid food and what I keep raving about. Though next time we'll probably bring our Cards Against Humanity.
author: Michael C.

description:
Came in for brunch this last Sunday with a group of friends and had an excellent time. 

All the food we got was fantastic, I can personally recommend the breakfast chicken slider, the fried egg slider, the potatoes, and the bottomless mimosas! The service was excellent - from the ladies that took our orders inside to the gentleman that never let our bottomless mimosas hit the bottom. Get there early, we got there around 11:30 on a Sunday and the place was already packed! They also have games you can play while you're eating and drinking, lots of fun! 

Really had an awesome time and will be going back sometime soon!
author: Emily H.

description:
At first Sycamore just looks like your average dive bar. Then you get ahold of the menu (featuring goodies like fried mac 'n cheese balls, pork belly donuts, and mix & match sliders) and venture to the back terrace, and it's like a whole new place crackling with possibilities.

Though it's not the cleanest place and the fare is kinda overpriced, the food is still tasty and, more importantly, there is a fun communal vibe here. My boyfriend and I stopped here for a late lunch on a Saturday afternoon and were immediately invited to join a game of Cards Against Humanity with a group of complete strangers. Apparently this is not unheard of here -- everyone is friendly, just chatting, playing other games (all provided by the bar -- just ask the bartender) and drinking beer and wine (no cocktails, sadly).

Great daytime alternative to the Zeitgeist when you're looking for something a bit more chill.
author: Tiffany W.

description:
The front is kind of like, "Okay, another divey bar, whatever, fine" but you walk through a tiny corridor and you're outside in the backyard area and all of a sudden everything changes.

Not because it's less divey because it still is with its old wooden benches and how tightly crammed everything is, but because of the inherent feeling that drinking outside is just BETTER. Also, their Moscow mules were good. Any time you give me a fancy copper mug, I am DOWN.
author: Rosy H.

description:
I remember when this place used to be the crazy Country Station Sushi joint. This has always been a small place but always fun.

I've come in a few times in the afternoon for a beer or two. The pork belly donut is a bit cloying for me but not too bad.

Overall this is a chill spot to get a beer and chill. I haven't been at night but it's quite cool for me.
author: Art O.

description: Needed to find a new bottomless mimosa spot. Thought this would be the spot.Food was quick and delicious, drinks kept coming, and service was just great! Here's where it gets gross. Yes, gross. When I came back from the restroom, I noticed my friend had a bug bite on her cheek. Wasn't there before. Then she went to the restroom and when she came back she pointed out a bug bite that I just got on my cheek bone and one on my hand. Mind you we were sitting on the counter. Then after I left got home and noticed bug bites around my ankles! I was wearing shorts that day and didn't go anywhere else other than this place. It really sucks but I'm sure we got bit here. So much for cleanliness. So just for that we won't be coming back.
author: Heather Q.

description:
How have I not rated this place yet? Been about 5 times, and so far is my favorite place is the city for brunch. Love, love, love. 

Ok, here's why....

Atmosphere. The best part about this place. People that work here don't really give a shit about what you want, but in a good way. For example, there is no decaf coffee or artificial sweetener because, well -- why should there be? It's kind of like being over at your family's house for brunch, unless you hate going to your family's house for brunch, then it's better than that. 

The food is amazing. Pork belly donuts, all kinda of sliders, waffles with bacon -- the list goes on.

All-you-can-drink mimosas. And, the woman who comes around and keeps them filled is awesome. Once I was there and we celebrated someone's birthday by doing a waterfall thing where everyone had to finish their mimosa before the next person started. It was great!

They have an outside patio, small inside area, and bar. The place is small, so you may have to wait. However, we've been lucky by getting there prior to noon (normally on Sunday's). 

There is really not enough good things I can say about this place. Definitely check it out!!!!!
author: Derrick S.

description:
While I wouldn't come back for brunch, I would definitely come back for beers.

I walked in and knew that we would order at the bar before finding a seat, but had the unfortunate experience of ordering from a not-too-friendly bartender who was incredibly sarcastic and even rolled his eyes once or twice. WHY? I'm still not sure. Having been in the food service industry before, I tried to mentally picture what I could have said to tick him off, but really... It came down to: He's having a bad day or... He's a huge douche. 

Regardless, the rest of the staff were amazing and laidback, and made sure that our bottomless mimosas were filled at every given minute. Come for the weekend bottomless mimosas, if anything.

The food... On the bright side, it was fast, and I was hungry.

But the food... 

We got the roast beef sandwich and an order of the large chicken and waffles. What a joke. The roast beef was underwhelming and the only redeeming quality of the dish was the fries. The chicken and waffles had about two McDonalds chicken nugget sized pieces on top of almost burnt waffles (THIS IS A LARGE?!). There was hardly enough syrup on the plate, and so we just had... well. Burnt chicken nuggets and burnt waffles.

Yeah I'm good on food, but maybe if I was more buzzed or drunk, the food would have been awesome.
author: Colleen M.

description:
Decided to try Sycamore's brunch menu and bottomless mimosas. We came right when the doors opened at 10 am, so we did not have to wait to be seated. We ordered our mimosas and food at the bar, and then nabbed seats on the artsy outdoor patio. The patio seats filled up quickly, so we were glad we got there early! It was cool see so many people come and go and to be able to meet others since the patio seating is communal seating.

Atmosphere: Cool dive bar vibe with posters and stickers on the wall.

Food: 
1) Sycamore Chicken and Waffles: Cannot go wrong with chicken and waffles for brunch.
2) Bottomless Mimosas ($12): With Real OJ and champagne. The staff was pretty good about refilling whenever our cups were empty.
author: Angel G.

description:
If you could sum up the stereotypes and snobbary of the mission in one restaurant, it's the Sycamore. 

I'll start by saying yes, I did read the reviews but I took it with a grain of salt. We were craving some unhealthy brunch grub and endless mimosas, can you blame us?

When we walked in, we couldn't help but notice how tiny it was. About 10 tables in the main dining area, a smallish bar and a narrow hallway leading to a smaller patio. We didn't see signs so we lingered a bit only to be barked at by a waitress that its open seating. Due to it being peak brunch time, we opted for the bar. Rookie mistake #1. 

While I understand what they're looking to accomplish with the "do everything at the bar" approach, IMO, it's very poorly executed. I saw people at tables waiting for lengths of time for waiters, questions about the menu that the bartender tended to get frustrated over, etc. I don't think it's fair to throw all responsibility on one bartender for food orders, drinks AND keep bottomless mimosas flowing. 

Food: Yelp hyped up the pork belly donuts and I opted for the pulled pork sandwich (fact: you can not overdose on pork. google it). The pork belly donuts... this is what tipped the scale and brought us here. Yelp, I love you all, but ya let me down. I got lots LOTS of batter with a hint of pork, not pork belly. Maybe an off day, but I do know my pork belly and this wasn't it. I had high hopes, and unfortunately it crashed and burned. The saving grace was the pulled pork sandwich....easily one of the best ive had in SF. It was packed with beautifully marinated pork and the bread was nice and soft. This alone would make me come back.

Service: again, I feel for the bartender; Drowning in food orders, tap beers and mimosa maintenance. To be fair, It wasn't her fault for the not-so-chipper attitude, because I would be the same if not worse in her position. I can simply fault the restaurant in the operations department.

Ambiance: sardine-like seating in the main dining room and communal-sardine-like on the patio. If you're at the bar, you can either smell the bartenders breath or get bumped into by passers by in the narrow hallway heading outside.

If you have friends in town and want to show them the "character" of the mission in a small window of time, head to sycamore. In this, there will be no disappointment.

All in all, pulled pork, wonderful beers and bottomless mimosas....  These are a few of my favorite things.
author: Ryan L.

description:
Nutshell: Food is so-so. Service is lacking. 

Chicken slider was probably the best thing we had. Fries were pretty tasty. 

Pork belly donuts were laughable. 

Bartenders don't have the greatest of attitudes. Sure, you have a line full of thirsty patrons, but that doesn't mean you have to be rude to clients because of it. 

It's obvious the Sycamore couldn't care less about return customers. 

No sweat off either of our backs, I suppose. 

Makes me want to wear a pair of Google Glasses just to visit the place.....if I could actually afford them.
author: Aren A.

description:
We ended up stopping in here after a lengthy discussion about pork belly over the weekend.  I was comforted to know that there are others who share my love of this overlooked delicacy.  The Sycamore, so I heard from a local friend, has pork belly donuts.  After I woke up with smelling salts under my nose and a light concussion from passing out (this news was simply too much for me to handle) we made our way over here.

I'm sad to say though that they were out of them when we arrived.  Life's disappointments help us grow stronger--this is in the top 5, or maybe, the biggest one I've ever had.

How is this problem solved?  Well, it was solved by hanging out in one of the neatest little bars I've ever visited.  The Sycamore is located in a small corner alcove off Mission Street.  When I saw that it had a Dutch door, the top being open on an unseasonably warm afternoon in March, I knew I'd be in love.

The interior was something out of a storybook--rustic, warm, inviting and magical.  There's a selection of board games to choose from if you want to occupy an afternoon with some friends playing Scattergories or whatever game you happen to choose.  When we walked in it wasn't busy, and despite being out of pork belly donuts we settled on some beers and sat down to enjoy.  Some people were seated to the front finishing up a game and appeared to really be having a good time and enjoying life.

I had a couple PBRs for a couple dollars each and they were served ice cold in cans.  If I lived out here in this neighborhood I could see myself frequently enjoying this place.  One of my friends got a few of their sliders--they have various ones, including lamb and a fried chicken one--and she thought they were great.

I plan to return on my next visit and hope to waste away an afternoon eating pork belly donuts, playing chutes and ladders and sipping on PBR in cans.  This is the stuff dreams are made of--and I can see mine coming true here, at The Sycamore.
author: Jared E.

description:
PORK. BELLY. DONUTS.

ARE YOU LISTENING SAN FRANCISCO.

GODDAMMIT.

TRY THEIR GOAT CHEESE AND FRUIT SALAD wait caps lock

Try their goat cheese and fruit salad so you can feel better about consuming the forewarned.

Maybe you should also keep your voice down when discussing your sexual preferences.

I'm talking, of course, about myself.
author: Jaime L.

description: The staff here were super nice suggesting drinks and the patio at the back is a nice touch. Since the inside is quite small, the back heated patio is nice for large groups as they have big tables there. It's a bit of a hole in the wall, but there's nothing wrong with that. Board games available if needed.
author: Ranee W.

description:
A good staple Mission establishment. I've been here twice now - once for drinks, beers are reasonably priced, and another for brunch ($12 mimosas with an $8 minimum). I'm not really sure why I understand the $8 minimum.. but anyway, mimosas were great and I appreciated their constant refills ;-). They weren't as bubbly as I would've liked but hey they were $12. I also had their fried egg sliders with tomato and they were super good and a good breakfast compliment to the mimosas.

I'd def come back for drinks/bottomless mimosas/other shenanigans.

FYI - they have an outdoor seating area but no umbrellas for shade :(.
author: Christina C.

description:
The food here is very heavy. I'm pretty sure it's what heartattacks are made of.

That being said, everything was pretty delicious. I had the Sycamore chicken and waffles (only one serving). The stuffed waffle was a little too much for my taste, but the chicken was super delicious.

I also had the pork belly donuts which was just way too much fat. But they ended up melting in your mouth. I guess for me it was a texture thing. Too much fat. 

Everything was reasonably priced though.
author: Angela L.

description:
This review is for brunch, and particularly for the chicken and waffles.

I was so disappointed by the chicken and waffles. Sweet + savory = delicious. Sweet + savory + very salty = nope. I wish they didn't stuff the waffles with prosciutto and manchego cheese. Then again, without the structural integrity of the stuffing, the waffle was limp. And the chicken was only 'meh.' It reminded me of chicken that you buy from the frozen section and heat up in an oven, because it lacks that really satisfying crisp outside.

Do order the pork belly donuts - those were amazing! That was exactly the sweet & savory combination I'd been craving. This ended my meal on a positive note.

Do not go on a hot day, unless you can find space outside. They don't use or have A/C and all the windows create a greenhouse effect that was miserable. Definitely pull the drapes closed if you're inside on a hot day.

My boyfriend had some sort of egg Benedict, which looked really good and gave me food envy after the first bite of my c&w.
author: Krista J.

description:
There's something charming and fun about the fact SF is littered with some of the most unassuming and amazingly awesome bars, and the Mission is a hot bed for them. After a great meal at a local hot spot, a friend of ours took charge and lead us down Valencia, then down a dark alley and right into The Sycamore. If I didn't know the neighborhood at all, I'd have been a little leary walking in because there's nothing special about the bar area. A small room with dark walls, lots of posters and s*it hanging from the walls, and a narrow, dimly lit hallway at the back. The beer selection is small and succinct, but it's complete and includes everything from lagers to double IPAs, draft and bottle. I settled into a Bombay by Boat IPA from Moonlight Brewing and was whisked down the narrow hallway, which happily opened to a sweet courtyard with rows of picnic bench style seating that encourages you to get friendly with your neighbors.

It was bingo night, not the blue haired grandma game you're thinking of, but a raunchy, rowdy, and lively game with an awesomely animated caller that looked like Saul Goodman. The other patrons happily invited us to get in on the last game, and in the middle we were all rewarded with free jello shots! It appeared that I missed bingo by one number, but when reading back the winning card, I heard my missing number! Bummer, but it made for an awesome Yelp photo!

I'm definitely the low key, divey, hole in the wall kind of guy, as long as there's good beer and company, and the Mission is home to oh so many good spots. The Sycamore delivered on all fronts, and I was only sad that I had no appetite to enjoy what is supposed to be great food. Next time I'm in SF, I will definitely be back with room to chow down.
author: Michael T.

description: Good beer choices like a blueberry stout.  Yum.  Chill staff and vibe.  Hailey is the amazing cook who comes up with such deliciousness as a donut burger on Thursdays and other nights.
author: Jorge R.

description:
You had me at "Pork Belly Donuts"..... with Makers Mark Glaze.
I knew my stomach and I were gonna pay dearly for it later, but I didn't care. I wanted to try it, I made it a mission to check this place out before I left SF. 

This local Mission bar is the perfect place for casual date nights, hanging out with friends or if you just want to come by to get some work done on your laptop. Whether you're an 8-5 office geek, hipster or a marathon biker (there were two dudes fully decked out in their gears & helmets dining)- the staff will warmly welcome you with a smile & a pint of beer. 

FRANZISKANER HEFE WEISSE ($5): 
Nice citrusy finish (I didn't even have to use the lemon like I normally do with most hefes). You can taste the bananas & cloves in this pint of deliciousness!
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/wNcShx5YTSMvOxt6G0iA9w?select=pS0P1y4KSDdy8qoS4mQH-w

The decor of this bar gives off a rocker-ish vibe with it's brightly painted red walls, black furnitures and black & white framed artworks. There's a classy, yet comfortable & unpretentious vibe to this place. 

Their back patio is the area to be. There's a very cool framed artwork on their wall, complete with a flowing waterfall. The owners used picnic tables and tree stump stools to keep with the whole "sycamore" theme. 

I particularly like the mini private area, located on your left as you enter the back patio. Come early if you wanna snag this spot for your friends.
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/wNcShx5YTSMvOxt6G0iA9w?select=NHn3S3epnO2XrugTVKa6dQ

PORK BELLY DONUTS w/MAKERS MARK GLAZE ($4 for 3 donuts):
It sounded like a good idea, but the execution & flavors fell short.  

The beer-braised pork belly just tasted like plain pork belly, no seasonings and I'm missing the salt.

The beer batter donut was thin, yet it got soggy & greasy REALLY fast. The combination of the greasy batter combined with the melt-in-your mouth pork fat makes every bite heart-clogging & rich. After the first donut, I ate the rest sans the dough. 

I didn't get any bourbon taste from the glaze. Just tasted like plain maple syrup.
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/wNcShx5YTSMvOxt6G0iA9w?select=VdfAmms0ZEqmjilgDWQjMw

Inside shot of the Pork Belly Donuts. Fat, fat & more fat!!
This one's for you, Cesar R!!
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/wNcShx5YTSMvOxt6G0iA9w?select=-HqPnP3O0zIVjuYORKc_mA

SLIDERS ($3.50 each slider, add fries for extra $1):
This was the best part of our meal. My only complaint was its choice of dinner rolls used for the buns. It wasn't toasted on the outside & was sort of dry.

We got one of each to sample: ground beef, lamb burger, fried chicken & fried catfish.
So stinkin' cute & tastes delicious! 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/wNcShx5YTSMvOxt6G0iA9w?select=4qQHRWbH5CP3szyETuzSAQ

BEEF SLIDER:
The ground beef is cooked to the right temperature. The roasted garlic aioli wasn't overpowering and provided the right amount of moisture to the bun. The sweet caramelized onions and blue cheese complimented each other really well, and helped bring out the sweetness in the beef. Very juicy, very flavorful.

LAMB BURGER:
Just as flavorful and juicy as the beef burger. 
The manchego cheese compliments the lamb very well, there was a peppery bite to it, which I liked very much. The romesco sauce was rather weak & watery. I didn't get the nutty-garlicky tomato flavors much, even though there was a large chunk of tomato on my burger.
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/wNcShx5YTSMvOxt6G0iA9w?select=RyqdcI-CfydcAoth5rFmKQ

FRIED CHICKEN BREAST & FRIED COD FISH sliders ($3.50 each):
Out of all the fried items, the Fried Chicken Breast Slider was my favorite and the Fried Cod Fish slider was a close 2nd. Yep, pork belly donuts was last....  
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/wNcShx5YTSMvOxt6G0iA9w?select=VaPWSfbhQor-t152CuJdCg

FRIED CHICKEN SLIDER:
At 1st glance, the chicken looks thin & dry but that all goes away when you bite into it. The chicken is crunchy (not at all greasy) and seasoned well. I could eat a few pieces of this without its other components. 

The menu said there was pickled red onions & cole slaw. All we got on ours was a bunch of lettuce and a garlic aioli. Np, since i was willing to eat the tasty chicken all by itself.
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/wNcShx5YTSMvOxt6G0iA9w?select=fzpEmD3AY9JScn_cfqKKbQ

FRIED COD SLIDER:
The menu & bartender said "catfish" but it was cod. It looked & tasted like cod. I hate catfish, it tastes like dirt to me.... and this fish burger didn't taste like catfish. 

Same batter used for the pork donuts = soggy greasy mess. Served w/sriracha aioli & house pickles. I wouldn't order this again.
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/wNcShx5YTSMvOxt6G0iA9w?select=04IjHZSVKbLfZ88ScE2VOw

CAPRESE SALAD w/basil vinaigrette ($7): 
We got one healthy item, lol. 
The mild, soft Bocconcini mozzarella really absorbed the flavors of the tasty vinaigrette. YUM!
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/wNcShx5YTSMvOxt6G0iA9w?select=po53QH5RYXfOe4i4Bj36Gw
author: Cin T.

description:
Why have I not written a review for my favorite bar yet? Maybe because bars like this don't give a fuck about yelp reviews - and I respect that. 

Good beers, good (albeit slightly pricey) food, and great people who work here. Come for trivia on Mondays, or Bingo night on Wednesday. The atmosphere is friendly and laid back, the patio is amazing, and the selection of board games is top notch. 

I'm actually tempted to give it a low rating to keep people away. It's a small bar that's definitely worth checking out.
author: Zoe T.

description:
Wait, I haven't reviewed this yet?  Pork belly donuts!  On two trips, they've been fattier and more flavorful (yay rock salt!) than the ones at the Willows.  And their lamb sliders are solid too.

Fries were alright, fried chicken was meh.

But the Drake's stout was fantastic, even better than the Oak Town brown.

The divey, cramped vibe of this place is a little out of sync with the food... but the Patio out back is pretty sweet, if sometimes monopolized by bingo players.  

And here's the big secret win about this place: you can almost always get in here when Monk's Kettle is overbooked.
author: Aaron M.

description:
Terrible service. One guy was nice, but the girl behind the bar and the guy pouring mimosas where terrible and rude. We asked for more mimosas and they just told us to sit and they will bring it around. Hence, our cups remained mostly empty because they rarely brought the "bottomless mimosas".
 Food was NOT great. They did not have chicken and waffles, so we got the pork belly doughnuts. Those where just deep fried pork belly balls covered in syrup - nothing to do with doughnuts. In our party of 7, no one even wanted to finish them. Also got the eggs Benedict, potatoes where good, but eggs did not have a good flavor.
author: Vlad S.

description:
Need a spot in Mission where you can eat good foo, drink good beer and wine, play games, and have options for your seating needs AND bring a dog? Gottems. 

Sycamore is a small corner neighborhood spot, super relaxed and encouraging of the community getting together for a good brew, conversation, and evening in the city.

Their beer selection is pretty bomb, filled with a variety of craft beers for errybody. They have food for your drunchie liking. I'm on that pork belly donut tip. Yes is it exactly what it sounds like. Yes, it's absolutely delicious and not good for the longitivtiy of your health. Good for thee soul though.

They have a variety of games you can playing under the influence with the peeps. Definitely a spot for thee board game lovers in the hood. Also have trivia nights and random events to encourage patrons to come in and have a good time.

The location is pretty awesome as well. Want that dark pub hole in the wall where you can scheme your evil plans or have a good talk with the awesome staff, or want a summer (or winter) night out on the patio area with a lot of seating area, lights for thee chillax ambience, and wall playing random old school movies while you play cards against humanity and smoke a pipe? Here it is. And you can bring your dogs out. If I had a dog, I would totes bring them. Maybe even my potential cat. Or bird.

Would love to make this a consistent spot!
author: Kristine T.

description: Great brunch with bottomless mimosas! Downside is only one bathroom for all clientele :(
author: Josh B.

description: Awesome patio with long tables and cool graffiti. Great place to hang out with a group with some drinks and some boardgames. Order your food and drinks at the small bar near the front. Fries were really good, sliders were okay. At night they were projecting Willy Wonka's Chocolate Factory on repeat on the patio, which I found hilarious.
author: Victor S.

description:
HEY, SYCAMORE. 
You think you're smooth, huh. Takin us on a trip to FLAVOR TOWN.

Man.

If someone were to describe me as a food, I'd be a Pork Belly Donut w/maple Makers Mark glaze. 

Pork Belly, cuz, well. I mean.
Donut, cuz, well. I meaaan...
Maple cuz I'm sweet. (Come on)
Makers Mark cuz I'm a whiskey chick. 
Glaze cuz I'm smooth and slippery and glossy. Chicka bow wow

But foreal doe. We ordered a gang a sht, like the tilapia spiders, fried chicken sliders, fried Mac n cheese balls w/a jalapeño cream dipping sauce sorta situation, and fries.  All tasted amazing to me.  Maybe it was cuz I had a horrible day at work and what might've been mediocre food tasted like monumental life changing food BUT I BEG TO DIFFER cuz my palate ain't that whack, even on a bad day. And those fries though? Nothin avant-garde bout em. They were just fries. But my friend and I were like DAMMMNNN these are crackin!!! Seriously, like we were on that ganja. My friend was all, man these are perfectly seasoned. And I was like yeah and perfectly crisp. It got deep. It was all very profound. 

Then we had the pork belly donuts.  Lawdy.  We got all serious again and I said, why'd you fckin take me here?  And went on and on about how interesting and perfect they were.  Pork belly donuts?  Who.does.that? All mad n sht. That's when you know something's good. You get all upset cuz now you know it exists.

Hahhaa I just re-read my review and saw that I typed tilapia spiders. Totally meant sliders. Could you imagine. Tilapia spiders. 
Scary!!
Well, wait. .. actually

Nope

Still scary

See ya
author: Rho T.

description:
This is a cool spot.  Great beer selection and reasonable price.  I tried the pork belly donuts and was not a huge fan.  It was a fat that was breaded and deep fried.  Maybe it was an off night?  

Staff was friendly as well.  Would definitely go back.  :-)
author: Paul W.

description: 1st visit was decent. 2nd try was horrible came in  bartender was rude, sat for over 10 min without any service, it was Sunday night only 2 other tables were occupied so it was not busy at all. Very disappointing. Ended up leaving.
author: Armando C.

description:
Fantastic place. Divey feel, small, intimate. 

Got brunch here last Sunday with a couple of friends and enjoyed bottomless mimosas, Cards Against Humanity, and pork belly donuts. You have to order your food and drinks at the bar, but they certainly like to keep the mimosas full! If any of our glasses got to be halfway full, someone would swoop in and fill it right back up to the brim--it was great. 

They have outside seating as well, but it was raining so we passed on that. Instead we chilled in front of the window on a number of cushioned benches--good for a large group. The bar had an awesome chandelier made of different beer taps and there was a shelf of tons of different games (Apples to Apples, Candy land, Clue, you name it and it's probably there)

Like many others, I recommend the pork belly donuts, they're a perfect amount of sweet and salty. The other brunch food is pretty solid as well, we all left with our bellies full wanting to come back some other time for some sliders and beer.
author: Liza X.

description: Unless there's a pool table involved, I don't frequent most dive bars, but Sycamore is one I make an exception for. Tasty eats, tucked away patio, interesting patrons, and of course, the ever changing selection of local draughts and craft brews are what make this place worth paying a visit. Jukebox, board games, trivia night, and down-to-earth, no-nonsense staff add to its character. Come for the beer, stay for the conversation you fell into with that guy with the weird piercings.
author: Megan D.

description: Pork filled donut holes were unbelievable. Spicy peanuts were simple but incredible too. Great beer selection and good vibes all around.
author: Ryan P.

description:
A place that is well past its prime.
To start the food is really disappointing here - everythjng is over salted and/or covered in something to cover up for the fact that what is being served is not exactly fresh off the grill/stove. Beers are being served in very small glasses but being charged as per a regular glass. Disappointing but I guess all places eventually run their course.
author: Rich S.

description: This place checks all the boxes and deserves 10 stars. From the service to the food, my gf and I were impressed with every single thing. I forget the exact name of the dish but the item with carnitas was so f good and the sliders were inexpensive yet really tasty. The workers were competent yet incredibly friendly and I wish I knew their names so I could shout them out for the way they treated us yesterday.
author: Amit D.

description:
Came here for brunch.  Was disappointed.

I had the smoked salmon benedict, which I assumed was like lox, but actually, the salmon was from a can.

I also had biscuits and gravy, and it was only okay.

We originally sat at a seat closer to the door, but it smelled like pee so badly that we had to move.  

I might come back here for drinks, but for food, probably not.
author: Max P.

description:
This place is small but it's a nice little space. My friend and I could only get seats at the bar but it was right in front of the bartender and she was super nice. 

We ordered:

-pork belly donuts: I came for these, and they didn't disappoint so I'm happy! The pork belly inside was tender and just melted in our mouths. So good. The donut that was wrapped around it was crunchy and the sauce on it was yummy. The donut to pork belly ratio was just the right amount too and wasn't too dough-y.

-two lamb sliders: it was the tiniest slider I've ever seen but it was very flavorful and tasted so good. I'm usually only okay with lamb because sometimes that distinct lamb flavor is a little too strong for me....but this was bomb. Finished it in two bites!

-also got two glasses of white sangria

Good experience overall!
author: Kelly T.

description:
The Sycamore is like the X mark on a treasure map. To get to it, you must endure the hostile environment of the 16th Mission bart station and also wade through several sketchy Mission pirates. If you are indeed a fearless young lad, the Treasure of the Sycamore is yours.

The treasure chest is compiled mostly of Pork Belly Donuts, which is arguably just as valuable as gold. Most definitely money in your mouth. It's obviously fat, oily and pretty much unhealthy. But it's good enough that you'll already have told you diet to walk the plank. Crunchy and crispy on the exterior, oily and fat in the interior. Words don't do it justice, and neither do the pictures. So get your brunch voyage crew ready and sail to the Sycamore to experience it yourself!

Arrrrr matey, cheer to your new found treasure with a bottomless mimosa : ) Just wear neutral colors though haha
author: Ringo M.

description:
If you can get the bartender to stop talking to all his hipster friends, and get stink eye from the hipster because we might actually want to order something, you can get some surly attention. I guess running a business is secondary to "hanging with the Hippy wannabes"
Food sucks, patrons and place are dirty and you feel like you need to wash your hands all the time. Anyone who isn't trying to look "cool" is just ignored and given condescending looks. God forbid that the bartender could actually do something besides talk non stop. 
At least they can't ruin the beer, only saving grace. 
Stay away unless you haven't shaved or washed in a couple days, and can rock the rolled up jeans with sneakers look....
Seriously, I saw it in person!
author: Fred S.

description: As always the best food and people ever love everything about the place will come back here every time we are in the city
author: Marsala T.

description: Nice rotating tap and unique street-corner vibe. Food seemed cool though I didn't get a chance to try.
author: Willy A.

description:
As if we do not already have enough reasons to visit the Mission, along comes another decent gastropub worth checking out.  We found our way to the Sycamore eager to try the much-hyped Pork Belly Donuts with Maple Makers Mark Glaze.  That's right, a pork belly donut, a  combination of two things I love, but not one my heart will approve.  I was actually worried that I might get addicted to those things, because at 3 pieces for $4, they're certainly priced appropriately.  The verdict?  Good but not great, like all other items we tried.  Overall, the Sycamore is a pretty solid spot.

The pork belly donut was a tale of two cities.  The donut part was amazing...perfectly fried, light, and airy.  The dough had a nice sweetness, and was perfectly complemented by the sea salt.  The pork belly, however, fell short.  I thought it was very bland and not very tender.  Also beware, the donuts actually look much better in photographs.  Still, I think this is an appetizer worth checking out.  If you come in with the right expectations, you'll probably enjoy them.

Also well above average was the Sycamore Roast Beef Sandwich, supposedly their signature sandwich.  (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/wNcShx5YTSMvOxt6G0iA9w?select=FCmUPX1c0kGywIO6v4hvHA)

I had it with both the mayo and special sauce...such a hearty and filling sandwich packed with a generous helping of thinly sliced beef.  The meat was warm, juicy, flavorful and tender.  The sauce, however, was a little on the sour side.  I'm not a fan of vinegar-based bbq sauces.  Finally, no complaints about their french fries.  The fries were seasoned properly and fried perfectly.

To be honest, I've been going back and forth from three to four stars.  I'm settling on a four because the items here are above average and priced fairly, though some adjustments are necessary.
author: Angel S.

description:
great pork  belly donuts if you eat them immediately. they get soggy very quick!!! 

i love the vibe at the sycamore,  but if you come late, expect to stand there staring at people awkwardly in hopes that they'll stop asking for refills of their bottomless mimosas and playing candyland so you can have a seat.
author: Judy L.

description: Great brunch! Saturday and Sunday.  Good Benedict, great waffles.  Bottomless mimosa are consistently being poured into my glass.  Hard to find a spot to sit though.  Get there early, you will be happy you did.
author: Jessica S.

description: Went for brunch with my friends. Good bloody mary and delicious brunch. Everyone loved the pork belly donuts. And the bottomless mimosas is a huge plus! Just know it get packed, and can be hard to find seating.
author: Diane S.

description:
OMG WHAT A HIDDEN GEM!!!

If you have the chance, you MUST do brunch here.  Myself and two of my girlfriends met up at this spot based off of one of my gf's sisters suggestion.  We were not sure what to expect (we assumed 'cutesy brunch spot') ...well we walked up to this little corner spot, with maybe 5 tables and a standing room only bar...BUT quickly found they have a great little space outdoors in the back. They don't take reso's and it is a first come first find a spot kind of joint but it is worth a little elbowing...or table sharing for the food.

You'd be surprised at this little hole-in-the-wall, it serves up some INCREDIBLE breakfast/brunch items and they also have an all-you-can-drink mimosa deal.  As many of the other reviews mentioned...you MUST MUST MUST, seriously this is an order...must try to pork belly 'donuts'.  They will blow your mind.  

This is exactly what you want from an SF brunch spot. The staff was super friendly and the crowd is, for lack of a better word, eclectic.
author: Alexandra P.

description: Great afternoon spot, the pulled-pork & fries were great. They take cards, amazing. Dive-ish enough with $6 drafts & $10 sandwiches. The bartender, Jen, knew everyone's name - love an atmosphere like that. Will definitely be back, but would hate to see the crowd when it's crowded.
author: Phil O.

description: Try their famous roast beef sandwich, duh. Anytime I visit San Francisco, I make this a must-stop.
author: Garaputo G.

description:
Was told this place was a go-to for their pork belly donuts. Did not realize it was a dive bar.

First impression: The street smells like piss so, because it's an opened-door dive bar, I can still smell the grimy streets. 

Tried their sliders: 3
  It's not amazing, neither is it awful. Average. They put a small handful of fries to go with it.

Pork belly donuts: 3
  You can taste a bit of the maker's mark... There are chunks of pork belly inside. Overall... It's not a donut, more like fritters. It's not awful either... Nor is it amazing good.

Overall: meh, the odor of the streets had already disappointed me from the beginning. Not the type of food I'd boast and crave about.


Not what I expected- the person who referred me here will sure hear from me!
author: Vangie A.

description: Love this spot. Food is great, beer is amazing, chef is fucking awesome. Can't say enough good things.
author: Sam A.

description: Pork belly donuts + great beer & great service!  Greatest pork invention known to man!  Enough said!
author: Ryan S.

description:
Blood red walls
Zebra print plush pillows
Sultry music
Chess, Othello, and Scrabble
Bartend(ress) strait out of LA ink. 
The stench of the Mission.... aka urine    (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/wNcShx5YTSMvOxt6G0iA9w?select=qzRg4FXyklYr66k10lpJlA)

Ahhh...  lunch with the coworkers. 

I checkmated the newest guy in our group twice. That's how long it took our food to come out. Kat Von D was cool in hooking up some quarters for the parking meter though. Parking tickets suck.  

More hipster haven than dive, consumed the following from SF's latest gastropub. 

1. Sycamore's famous roast beef sandwich.... tender cuts of roast beef slathered in this bbq/mayo sauce. Added fries for $1 more. It reminded me of Arby's. Not enough meat to justify it being called Man Food though. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/wNcShx5YTSMvOxt6G0iA9w?select=z-psOOTEAPchBwYUWWCk5Q) 

2. For the love of bacon! My eyes popped out their sockets once I saw that they had PORK BELLY DONUTS w/ Maker's Mark maple glaze ($5). Crispy, sweet, salty, juicy, fatty. They reminded me of a Mcgriddle. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/wNcShx5YTSMvOxt6G0iA9w?select=cGyIfHgzt_nQT9cL_K4upQ)

Mr. Checkmate said beef, chicken, and lamb - in that order for the sliders. 

3 star food. 4 star ambiance. 5 star service. 1 star smell. 

If you like this you'd probably like Broken Record and the Tee Off Bar
author: Earl G.

description: Delicious Eggs Benedict. Bottomless mimosas are ok. They weren't really all that cold and you have to wait a bit to get refills, but those are trivial complaints. Overall very good. Recommend to all. They have a back patio area as well so it kinda seems like they won't be able to accommodate anyone but it's actually pretty big.
author: Chad W.

description:
Date & Time:  Monday July 19, 2010 @ 6pm
Dining Companion:  The Husband
Scene:  Cute Guys in Ironic Slogan Graphic Tee's, Levi's Capital E Jeans, Hoodies, Sneakers & Rickshaw Bagworks Messenger Bags
Music:  JukeBox w/ Good Selection:  The Clash, Elvis Costello, Early David Bowie, Trainspotting & Swingers Soundtrack
Vibe:  Chill
Decor:  Cool Small Space.  Red Walls w/ Framed Sketches.  Dim-Lighting & HardWood Floors.  Bar & Cushioned Bench Seating w/ Zebra-Striped Pillows.  Back Patio w/ Lanterns & Picnic Benches 
Service:  Warm & Welcoming 
Imbibe:  Beer
Devour:  2 of Everything on The Menu:  House-Marinated Olives & Nuts, $3 Mini-Sliders:  Fried Chicken, BLT, Burger & Lamb, Pulled Pork Sandwich & N. Shore Outta Massachusetts Hot Roast Beef Sandwich
Total:  $46
author: Genevieve Y.

description:
Came here to have their bottomless mimosa during brunch...I guess I could say it was the best part of our meal.  At $12, it was a very good deal...  The servers made sure our glasses were always full..plus they use Odwalla orange juice (with lots of pulp!)  which made it better (in my opinion, at least)

Since people have been raving about their pork belly donuts, we decided to get that, plus the breakfast chicken slider,  bacon/egg slider and the country omelet.
I was a disappointed with the overall taste and food portions.  The chicken slider was tasteless...even WITH the gravy. There was nothing special about the bacon/egg slider and the country omelet.   I was hoping for a bigger serving (or yummier food).  The pork belly donuts (I didn't have this but my husband did) were ok though.  He found them nice and tender - but nothing to crow about.

This was a cozy little spot with comfortable bench seating (although the cushions were dirty), and a huge patio in the back. The staff was attentive and friendly.   However, I am not coming back here for brunch.
author: Anj K.

description:
This is a new small neighborhood bar on Mission street, http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/8uzZVXorHEtA2i65MsWETg/l located just a block and a half from the 16th St BART station. The place is very small but comfortable, just enough space for 5 stools, 6 tables and a jukebox on the left wall. There's also an equal sized outdoors patio with benches, in the back as u walk pass the bathroom.

Love this combination of a comfy space with good food (mostly sandwiches) and drinks. Click on these links to see the short bar food menu http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/aulaJpFxUtLLqTjA6K7p-A/l and drinks menu. http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/ZkmsBCwWhPvc-1hS2bD-ng/l

When I came in on Monday (first day), I was surprised to see a family with their kids having a meal. So although it's a bar it can be a family friendly spot too. Luckily it wasn't crowded yet, I'm sure that'll change as more people find out about this place. The simple menu includes 2 appetizers, 2 salads, a few bar snacks, sandwiches ($8) and sliders ($3). They even have a Seitan sandwich for vegetarians. Very friendly service.

I ordered their signature roast beef sandwich ($8) with BBQ sauce and/or mayo, plus choice of fries or side salad for $1 more. I got the side salad. http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/oUgyD229rC8wU6T90x75Jw/l The sando was delicious! The thinly sliced and SUPER tender roast beef meat was excellent. The easiest way to describe it would be: similar to an Arby's beef sammy but with top quality fresh ingredients instead, no processed meats.

I liked this place. It can be a nice lunch alternative to popular Yamo (fake Thai/Burmese food hole-in-the-wall) a block away. And adds more variety to the late night drinks and dining scene on Mission, with Rosamunde Sausage Grill and Nombe (Japanese food) nearby.

Hours: daily 11am-midnight, food service until 10pm.
author: Luis C.

description:
Dive bars are fine, except when they're filthy. Seriously, this place needs to get a mop and cleaning rag out. And maybe wash your dish ware. And give your patrons silverware to eat with. Yeeesh. Indifferent staff don't make it better or "cooler" either. I can get a beer anywhere peeps. 
The Mac n Cheese bites were the bomb tho. So were the Poppers. The two stars are for them. Mac n cheese 4eva! Viva la Poppers!
author: Sally S.

description:
I liked this place, as do many of the reviewers. But first, a warning. 

This is not a "nice" date spot, if you are looking for that kind of thing. The beer selection is great, the comfort food will make you think of home. If your date isn't going to enjoy eating friend macaroni and cheese balls with bits of bacon on picnic tables, look elsewhere. 

Come here with your peeps, unwind, enjoy the great vibe. It's a dive in the sense that there is no pretension and the atmosphere is for you to feel welcomed. Everything is a bit worn out, but in the way you wear out shoes. They are all the better for it.
author: Jake B.

description:
I love this place!  Many of the reviews classify this as a dive bar and as I do love my dive bars, I think this is a step up.  The back patio is perfect. It's so cozy there, I could stay all day.  The service was great! Lots of board games to play.  I love the barn style door.  They have great beer on tap and the food menu looked good, too, even though I didn't have any.

Can't wait to visit again!
author: Marianne S.

description: If you can manage to get a table inside, it's a great spot... Board games add to the hipster, Mission scene. Went for a tap takeover and the staff was really laid-back and friendly. Food was okay, thus the 4*s, but probably wouldn't be a good dinner atmosphere anyways. Didn't make it to the back but supposedly a great patio out there
author: Kerry G.

description:
This place is the ideal bar to grab a small bite and quick drinks. Completely unassuming, with a chill staff and more games than I can name, some friends and I stopped off here the other day to grab a drink.

Beer and wine only, but a good selection. Both the patio and indoors are great. When we were there, there was a lot of Biggie on. But, whatever.

Food was surprisingly good for a place that looks like it couldn't house a kitchen. While I didn't indulge in the pork belly donuts, every slider we ordered was delicious.

I mean, it's not the greatest food or bar in the whole universe. But if you're looking for an unpretentious place to meet people, it's here.
author: Kitt V.

description: We came here for Sunday brunch. I ordered 3 sliders (lamb burger, fried egg/sausage, and fried chicken)...they were terrific. The fried chicken with country gravy slider was a bit dry (the chicken patty) but I'll forgive them because the bottomless mimosas were just flowing non-stop. I'll give them 5 stars just for that! My buddies all enjoyed their breakfasts and bottomless mimosas too.
author: Ray G.

description:
What a gem. Never would I have thought walking by that this place was 5 star-licious!

A friend recommended we met up here for brunch and I love lil dive bars especially with good food reputation so I was game. We came in, were greeted by a super welcoming bartender. Then we were out in their back patio...I LOVE patios!

There's a good amount of seating outside on the picnic tables. We grabbed some menus and each ordered bottomless mimosas (only $12!) and they tasted great. Not cheap tasting like some other places I've been to. Love it already. Then, I see Maple Makers Mark pork belly donuts on the menu as we peruse it to see what goodies we should order to fill our hungry tummies. How could you not order a plate of those to share? They were phenomenal. Get some.

I got the veggie scramble which was fresh and delicious. My hubby got the biscuits and gravy which I tasted and although it's not my thing, it was really good. They even put over easy eggs on the biscuits. Yummers!

My other friend for the prosciutto and cheese stuffed waffles which I got a bite of as well and that is not only a smart idea, but it's amazingly delicious as well. It even came with a piece of chicken on top. Extra yum!

They also have board games you can borrow and they're all in great shape. I love this spot! I live outside of the city but will come back here again very soon. I mean, what's not to like? The staff is awesome, full of jokes, is super welcoming, the food preparation is quick, the prices are totally affordable, there's a back patio, good drinks, and it's just a feel good type of hidden gem. I'll be back again soon!
author: Akvile D.

description:
Went here for brunch this past weekend with some friends.

This place is really small and gets packed relatively quickly. They offer bottomless mimosas for $12 (if you purchase an entree of $8 or more). Surprisingly, they were really good at refilling out glasses (too good) and this actually made the wait for food SLIGHTLY more bearable. They must've been super backed up in the kitchen because I waited maybe 40+ minutes for my scramble. By the time my scramble arrived, I wasn't even hungry anymore and in all honesty, it was only mediocre at best. For $12+ dollars, the portion was also not very worth it.

Overall, I wasn't a fan and probably wouldn't come back.
author: Maggi K.

description:
The Sycamore has a great selection of some fairly obscure beers. They also have a healthy supply of board games, which is awesome.

The prices are reasonable, there's a back patio, and indoor seating with cushions. What more could you want?

I hear there's food, but I didn't partake.

The good: solid atmosphere.
The bad: don't sit by the door in the window. People come and go all night long  and it sure can be chilly.
author: Amanda B.

description:
Small dive bar with only a few tables inside. Food and drinks need to be ordered and paid for at the bar, but have no fear the one bartender they have literally does it all! They have some interesting beers, wines, and sangrias to choose from for whatever your heart desires. A plethora of boardgames are available for your pleasure, although majority of them look like they're at least 10 years old. 

We ordered:

Pork belly donuts: i could have done without the thick sweet batter, not sure why everyone and their mamas raved about this
French fries: nothing special, we were starving so we still gobbled them up
Fried mac n cheese: party in your mouth!! My favorite dish
Pan fried provolone: interesting concept, like eating a miniature pizza
Catfish slider, lamb slider: meh
Fried chicken slider: the best out of the 3! 
Grilled cheese: nothing special, came with MORE fries, oops

We absentmindedly ordered tons of fried foods and In terms of gastropubs, this one fell short. Not sure if the lack of parking and seating warrants another trip.
author: Vivian D.

description:
Went for brunch with my wife. Good bloody mary and delicious brunch.
It can get a bit messy as you have to line up and order at the bar, but they have a nice patio.
Overall pretty good- recommended for brunch on a sunny day.
author: Pablo A.

description:
I absolutely love the festive rustic atmosphere, one of the types of bohemian places I have come to love in San Francisco. Truly an awe inspiring beer selection, many things you don't see elsewhere.  And the short wine list is well vetted. We went in for late brunch, and the kitchen was starting to run low on quite a few items. Sadly, the chicken and waffles and the fruit plates were 86'd. We ordered an omelette smothered in gravy, and biscuits and gravy with fried eggs. It was delicious, but definitely stuck with us for a few hours. Not a light brunch by any means. The couple next to us ordered the burger and some sliders; I was enviously eyeing their plates, it looked beautiful. 

I would definitely hit this again for atmosphere and service but probably for a different meal than brunch just to see what else they offer.
author: Lizzie S.

description:
SO GOOD! went on saturday at about noon for bottomless mimosas and breakfast. i got 2 sliders with fried egg and bacon, which were a little dry but delisih, fries, and bottomless for 24 bucks! not too shabby... and the waitress was veryyyyy attentive with refilling the mimosas. prime.

A group of 9 of us got there like a half hour after it opened and it was very busy. the bathroom is disgusting and the inside is dark and grungey. but they have games! and theres a cute outdoor patio with a booth and some picnic tables... they usually have umbrellas but one was broken when we were there so we died in the heat... but that was just an unfortunate circumstance! all around great experience!
author: Christie B.

description: Nice little outdoor seating area, delicious food, and good service. Pulled pork sandwich is delicious. Also love the black bean burger. I didn't think I would like the Mac 'N Cheese balls, but they were surprisingly good. Cool spot on Mission.
author: Heather J.

description:
we love kim the mimosa ninja!


Seriously if one could give Kim 6 stars.. 


Delicious food and fun atmosphere. Small space but that just means it's exclusive ;)
author: Neek W.

description:
If you expect decent food, service and standards, steer clear of this place. 

The Sycamore is literally a dump. This place reeks of filth, with dirty floors, no ventilation, and in a shoebox of a location. I wouldn't even go as far to say this is a restaurant because it looks and feels like the opposite of one. I felt like I was breathing in asbestos and mold. 

The pork belly donuts are good but not great. Unfortunately, I ate salt balls in every. single. bite. The sweet maple (obviously) did not balance out the sodium clad balls . The pork was bland. The tempura batter is okay and has a chew but nothing impressive. The overall taste did not entice my taste buds. I felt that it was on the lower end of mediocre at best and not really creative in the realm of the Mission food scene.

We also ordered the fried chicken slider, the fried egg slider and the beef slider. The beef slider had a garlic aioli sauce which was the best of the three, although it might just be the mayo giving the slider flavor it wouldn't otherwise have. The fried chicken slider was very bland and had no real flavor. It was fried with no seasoning and finished off with 2 biscuits on either end. If I can say it looked like reheated frozen food, well, that was it. The biscuits tasted like cardboard - very dry, breaks after a bite. Uneven. Very greasy. Very meh.  The best part were the fries because you can't really mess that up.  

The worst thing was actually waiting for everything. We came at 11:04 on a Saturday morning. The place wasn't even half full yet. Food doesn't arrive until after 12:30. About 30 minutes in, I asked about my order and they said they were having problems with their oven and the biscuits were taking more time to be made. Ok fine. Wouldn't it be better practice to tell us that? She proceeded to ask if I wanted slider buns instead of the biscuits, so I said yes. It didn't come out any faster. At around 12, they shouted out to everyone in the dining room, "the oven's working, woo hoo!". Classy? No. To add more fuel to the fire, there were other people who came in later than us that received their food on time. It wasn't just eggs. It was the same things we ordered. It was just that ridiculous! We were about to leave but out comes our order and it was prepared in such a haste that the cheeses were still cold and not melted. 

Service was decent. Mostly everything is self service so you get your own water, or coffee. You pay first after you order from the counter. Find your own seat. I think the waitress saw how upset we were and offered us both complimentary mimosas, which were good but not great. I've definitely had better. It's not worth the $12 price even for bottomless. The orange juice is all opened in the back counter and it looks  very unsanitary. The pitchers were also not covered. When our sliders finally came, the waitress came and comped our sliders for the wait. That was good customer service on her part and I appreciate the gesture.  

To sum it up, I would not recommend this place for the reasons above. I didn't feel like this place lives up to its ratings on Yelp.
author: Jennifer N.

description:
I don't know what is so hyped up about this place. The chicken and waffles are not that great. The waffles are so salty inside because there's too much prosciutto and there's hardly any cheese. The chicken is just two small pieces of breaded/fried chicken. 

Their mimosas are really watered down. There's really no taste of champagne. The servers of mimosas aren't that hygienic either.
author: Glendie D.

description:
I have long loved their beer selection but damn this place has some seriously delicious brunch!
I got the carnitas benedict and it had perfectly crispy carnitas on a lovely toasted biscut with heavenly runny eggs.
Decent bloody too
I know you're thinking " I defininitely can go my whole life without pork belly donuts."
You are wrong. So . So . Wrong.
These are tiny bites of heaven and you will hate yourself for not trying them.
Also the outdoor patio is ideal for summer.
author: Molly S.

description:
Initially I was super apprehensive about this place... Hipster vibe partnered with hipster indie 'journalism'  coverage. 

Gross. 

But- 

Then I quickly realized what a cool spot it was! Pretty tiny inside, with a substantial patio outside. Some nice craft beer, nothing super special coming from the land of SF. The small plates, ohh, the small plates, this is where it got fun. I had the deep fried macaroni bites accompanied with the bacon wrapped jalapeño poppers. Get the fuck outta here. Delicious. I should never have judged. Keep it I guys.
author: andy s.

description:
Yay! I'm a fan! 

Yum, pork belly donuts! Perfect snack to a nice cold beer. They have a good variety of craft beers to choose from and bar bites to accompany them. Nice outdoor patio in the back also. It reminds me of a place I frequent here in PHX.
author: C L.

description: Good selection of beer, but extremely rude servers and bartenders. Ruined the evening. It's a shame that such a place can have such terrible service and allow such rude people to work there.
author: Adam Z.

description:
It's impossible to not like this bar. 

---Maker's Mark Glazed Pork Belly Donuts---
---REAL punk rock in the juke box---
---Awesome bartender---
---Nice constant rotation of craft beers--
---Incomplete board games, including "Operacion"---
---Mixed "eclectic" crowd---
---Outdoor patio---

The Sycamore is a shit hole with great music, good bites, and cheap beer. Hence, why we always stop in, when we're in the city.
author: Gino E.

description: Bottomless mimosas!! Pork belly donuts!!!! Chicken and waffles!! Yum!! Loud music,  nice  staff !!! Downside, there is not a lot of seating.
author: Elaine E.

description:
Great spot to hang out with friends on a sunny day over the weekend.

They have a patio & they allow dogs - awesome.

While the pork belly donuts were a bit too greasy & fatty for my liking, the fried mac & cheese balls with jalapeno & bacon were excellent. 

Service was a bit slow, but my group ordered a lot of food.
author: Grace C.

description: Great beer selection. The sliders were good but not on the cheap side for the size they are. The side salad was really good, I highly recommend ordering it .
author: Michèle S.

description: Great bar for friends, fun, sun, bottomless mimosas and a pretty good brunch. The food is always pretty good here, the service is excellent even though it's often packed. They're one of the better spots I've tried for bottomless mimosas as far as quality and speed of refill. The cards against humanity, other games offered, and an eclectic patio area for smoking, dining, and hanging, makes this a must try for a Sunday funday. Try the pork belly donuts.
author: Shannon C.

description:
Great beers on tap, great tunes, and awesome atmosphere.  A really great place to chat with friends.

The food is out of this world, I was super impressed with the Pulled Pork Sandwich.  It was savory and delicious.  The fries are on point as well.

If you want to get gabby in a warm environment, this is the spot!
author: Tarun B.

description:
Cannot express fully in words how perfect this brunch was given the circumstances. I was in SF for the Treasure Island music festival and we were hankering for a solid brunch option before heading to the 1st day of the festival.

The sliders were all tremendous. The Breakfast Chicken slider was my favorite, but the Fried Egg option was a good option for standard fare.

The Pork Belly "Donuts" were outstanding. As I sat basking in the sunshine on a rare October day, I took a bite out of said donuts. It was a revelation. A cosmic reaction was occurring in my mouth and I didn't give a damn what happened next. Seriously, these donuts were incredible. Never had anything like it before. A must order.

To top it off, the bottomless mimosa deal was as advertised. Not only was the orange juice fresh, the staff took "bottomless" to heart. Not once did I have an empty glass. It was glorious.
