Went with the pork belly donuts, each of their sliders, side of fries, and the pulled pork sandwich. The taste of the Makers in the pork belly donuts are very subtle but it's good nonetheless. Each slider was flavorful and their proteins really shined. The fries were nice and crisp like how Jack in the Box used to be before they swapped them out for the hand cut fries. But the pulled pork sandwich was staggering behind the other menu items we tried. 

Think I'll be back to try their brunch menu.

Oh yeah ... website menu prices are different than in store but not drastically so break out a couple more quarters for your grub.
author: Eric L.

description:
Oh Sycamore...I am hook, line, and sinker for you.

Let's start with the most obvious - $12 bottomless mimosas made with Odwalla orange juice. There is actually about 60% champagne in these bad boys but you can't taste it at all, just the juicy Odwalla goodness! If you're really desperate for drunkenness, this special lasts for 5 hours from 10-3pm on the weekends. 

Sliders and fries were great side noms to accompany my mimosa lunch. 

Btw servers were super attentive to my mimosa levels. I actually have no idea how many I drank because my glass was constantly refilled before it reached empty. Dangerously awesome!
author: Rachel R.

description:
Bottomless mimosas are only $8 with an order of food!  They were mostly orange juice, but they were definitely good about keeping them refilled.  Like most brunch places, there are no reservations, but it wasn't bad getting a patio table on a Sunday around 12:30pm.  I even found metered parking right in front.

Seat yourself, then go to the counter to order your drinks and food.   Coffee is $2, water is self serve.  Then, they bring the food out to you (pretty quickly).

Food:
- Chicken and waffles: Thin chicken breast, fried nicely, served over waffles.  These are not just regular waffles - they're stuffed with proscuitto and manchego, and I now strongly believe that's how all waffles should be made.  The Makers Mark maple syrup was surprisingly not too sweet.  Definitely get a double order.
- Pork belly donuts: Basically pork belly battered and fried.  The batter is somewhat thick outside, but the pork belly inside is generous, and the same syrup/glaze as above is crucial for covering the batter (otherwise, the batter doesn't have much flavor)
- Fried egg slider: Served on a biscuit. The egg had a perfectly runny yolk, sharp cheddar, and crisped bacon.  This was the best slider by far.
- Lamb burger slider: Not too gamey, went well with caramelized onions and manchego, served on a regular slider bun
- Ground beef slider: Well seasoned, topped with blue cheese, caramelized onions, and garlic aioli.  If you like blue cheese (which I do), you'll like this
- Roast Beef Sandwich: Thinly sliced roast beef, reminiscent of an Arby's sandwich.  The sauce was kind of like Arby's sauce (which I love), and it was generous on the meat.

I love the back patio, but it got pretty warm under the sun (try to find a seat under the big umbrellas).  I hear it's pretty cool for happy hour and at night, as well.  Brunch did not disappoint!
author: Marilyn H.

description:
Delicious sliders, amazing fries, constantly awesome beer rotation. This place is just a fantastic location with a great staff. Not only is the interior packed with board games and artwork, not only are the food selections amazing but the outside doubles as meeting space/theater. 

There are also ridiculous and awesome creatures drawn on the walls outside but watch out, if you are over 5'8'' you MAY get hit by the low hanging doorframe on your way out.
author: Andrew K.

description:
The server was a little presumptuous. After she handed me my pork belly donuts, she comes back and puts down several more forks and says to the rest of the table, "Just in case he wants to be nice and share." I would have offered my friends anyway but I don't like someone assuming what I would and wouldn't be sharing. 

Although I would like to like this place, eating in a dirty back patio on uneven, wobbly benches, with sub-par service just isn't something I look forward to for brunch. It has nothing to do with the scene, it's just that I think this place really is a bar at heart who just decided that they wanted to make brunch one day without doing any research as to how to do it correctly.

On to the food, it was all bland and not seasoned well. I usually don't put extra salt on my food but at this establishment I definitely had to employ the saltshaker many times. The pork belly donuts were underwhelming (and I LOVE pork belly usually) and the benedict I got was underseasoned. 

I would not come back here for brunch.
author: Rylan C.

description:
I had high hopes for The Sycamore, but alas, I feel very "meh" about it. To my surprise, this seems like an unpopular opinion!? 

I think part of the problem for me is that in addition to boozing, I've tried to eat an actual meal each time I've been. The food is awful! I've had the pulled pork sandwich, seitan sandwich, and a variety of brunch items - all very disappointing. But I think if I didn't treat it like a restaurant it'd be alright.

They do, after all, have some solid beers, like Racer 5, Allagash White, Black Butte, some stuff from Dogfish Head, etc. And games - games are fun! Scrabble, Connect Four, Operation... you'll find almost every table partaking in the fun. This has created a drunkenly innocent communal vibe though. Kind of like the dorms? It would definitely be a good place to hit if you just moved to the city and wanted to meet some new pals :)
author: Stephanie P.

description:
Sunday Mimosas are a hit! 
I enjoyed the mimosas and the ambiance. Its a pretty chill laid back spot. Get your menu and order your food from the bar. 
The food was so so, my friends and I ordered breakfast, but we saw others order appetizers which is what I would definitely do next time. 
The people were great. Bathroom is decent. 
I would come back for the mimosas and the great ambiance.
author: Brenda B.

description:
Ate here Nov. 3, 2012.

What makes this place really unique and cool is the ambiance and vibe! It's a true reflection of San Francisco hipster subculture! And the bottomless mimosas during weekend brunch don't hurt the experience either! =0)

BREAKFAST CHICKEN SLIDER = OMG! I just died and went to heaven good!! 5 stars!! Think of this item as a variation of Chicken & Waffles! Must order this!

COUNTRY OMELETTE = Mediocre. Nothing special! 3.5 stars!!

BOTTOMLESS MIMOSAS = The reason why I came here!!!  5 stars!!!

The wait staff gets 5 stars b/c they are attentive and cool as hell!

The only negative thing I have to say about this place and keeps this place from getting 5 stars in all is the flies buzzing around the back patio! I hate flies when I eat! It's not the most appetizing experience. Anytime else I don't mind but not when I'm sitting down and eating! Do you feel that way too about flies when you eat?
author: Victor C.

description: I endorse any bar or restaurant that not only encourages playing board games but has a lending library of them also! It's a little divey in appearance, has limited seating inside, and all ordering is at the bar, but otherwise it's great. Food is solid, 8 beers on tap, and bottomless mimosas from 11-3 on weekends ($12 with food). Game on!
author: Bill B.

description: Perfect place fur brunch with a date or a huge group of friends. The food is creative, different and so tasty. They have great prices and good service. Definitely a place I'll be returning to.
author: Lani A.

description: Popped in after reading the reviews and I was surprised to find the portions so small, but the prices so high. Also, most of the food was under seasoned. Probably won't return.
author: BigArm K.

description:
I'm pretty much obsessed with this place right now.

1. Shipyard Smashed Blueberry beer on tap.
2. Sliders -- lamb, beef, egg. UNREAL.
3. Patio out back which is perfect for a beautiful day.
4. BOARD GAMES.
author: Lauren F.

description:
Bottomless Mimosas on the weekend are, wait for it...............................actually bottomless!!! Seriously, I need to learn the ladies name who keeps the refilled but she does an amazing job, and I caught a peek that they use Odwalla juice? Whaaa? So good!

Their chicken and waffles was good, but the ham in the middle of the waffle was a bit much...I would've rather had a piece of bacon straight around my chicken or something. 

It can get crowded so beat the Mission-ites out and get there by like 11 and you'll be good. In the rain they have an ez-up so you stay dry! Woo!
author: Maggie F.

description:
Varied selection of beer, not bad lots of bottles and stuff. Service was pretty good, I felt the entire place was full of regulars and awesome people who visit the place often. The girl at the bar handled everybody one at a time with a smile on her face even though it was kinda of a lunch rush. 

- Pork Belly donuts are pretty good but I felt they were too greasy, and the pork inside one was good really well the other one was kinda soggy though. I would have to give them another try if I really wanted. 

- The sliders are pretty good, the biscuit was good and the ingredients they use are top notch. The chicken one had a delicious gravy on it, the lamb was ok I wasn't too impressed by it, and the fried egg one was pretty good though I don't think the quality of it was as good as the fried chicken and gravy one. 

I would say this place is more awesome for the crowd and decent selection of food even if it's not the greatest food in the world
author: Rohan D.

description:
Sycamore does NOT serve good food and it's not a gastropub by any means. It's a great bar, I loved the beer selection and service but having come there to eat lunch, I was seriously disappointed. 

The pork belly donuts (#1 reason why I had to go to Sycamore) were just deep fried pieces of pork belly, no donut there. Next on the menu was a butter lettuce salad with mixed berries and goat cheese, or so the menu said. In reality it was a giant bowl of butter lettuce, some strawberries, some blue cheese (they were out of goat cheese). Everything sounds much better on the menu than it really is.
author: Tatyana K.

description:
Here's what this place isn't:
- fancy
- big
- well-lit

Here's what this place is:
- full of unique and fun kinds of beers
- has board games, including bingo night
- serves a deep fried piece of pork with sugar on it (mmm fat kid mmmmm)
- great low key vibe
- small intimate and cute place to go with a couple friends (not too many there's not a ton of space)

Go here. Enjoy the vibe and drinks and bingo.
author: Shanee B.

description:
This place makes me miss Oregon. Coming down from Portland where similar pubs are everywhere, it's such a treat to find something like this. A good beer selection and even more in bottles. The star though is the delicious food. I had the pork belly donuts with maple makers mark glaze. Amazing. Though I'd probably a different choice of meat, one that would fall apart so i can enjoy the meat in both bites of my donut. The maple and makers mark glaze is well balanced where you get the taste of both and some sea salt on top to contrast the sweetness. delicious.

I also had the the beer battered catfish and this is another phenomenal. there isn't much to say about fish and chips but if you look at how the batter is light and crispy and the fish is tasty, what more do i need to say?

My last dish was... disappointing. It was the fried mac n cheese, which she sold me bacon with. I don't think the bacon made it in to my mac n cheese either that or it's so lost in there. The taste was OK, average at best but here is the killer, was that ranch dressing i had with it? talk about odd combination, should have sent out some of that sriracha aioli and it would have been a great pairing.
author: John T.

description: the sycamore is a great place to go for lunch. HUGE fan of the roast beef sandwich and a beer on tap called HOLYCRAFT - MAGNUM OPUS. The roast beef sandwich is juicy and the barbeque sauce and horseradish mayo is superb, wash it all down with this Belgium Style HOLYCRAFT MAGNUM OPUS and your taste buds will be craving it for weeks to come. My friend had the Burger and we shared the chicken sliders as well. All extremely tasty.
author: Steve S.

description:
We went for brunch.  The mimosas were weak...totally not worth the money.  And the bartender gave us a hard time for leaving half of our drinks when we got up.  Just lefty a bad taste in our mouths. 

The good thing is the food.  The chicken and waffles are killer and the chicken breakfast biscuits were awesome too.

I recommend this place for an early brunch, we didn't have to wait which is rare.  Don't expect a bubbly staff because its just a dive bar, but the food is totally worth it.
author: Chad J.

description:
Don't turn around.

Playing on the sound system: www.youtube.com/watch?v=INi7srItF6g

No longer playing on the menu: French toast with Makers Mark syrup. On this day they were out of the carnitas benedict too.

Former was the reason for returning. Latter caught the eye of my dining companion.

But that's no reason to leave.

You still get the exceptional service and scene I've written about previously.

Plus one can try a few more things. Like the vegetarian benedict featuring two poached eggs, kale, caramelized onions, potatoes and fruit.

Or double the fruit in lieu of potatoes. See what I mean about exceptional service?

Didn't love the benedict as much as the homemade granola on my second visit. Just a bit expensive at $13. Intangibles make it worth it.

Pork belly donuts were given a second chance and remain baffling.

Still wouldn't turn around. In fact likely coming back. Homemade black bean burger does sound good.
author: Jason B.

description:
It was my first time in The Sycamore...
the service was friendly enough, albeit a bit slow considering there was only one other party in the establishment and they'd been served already.
the sliders were m'eh, not bad, but not anything special, not anything that i'd write loquacious lines about. 

what really got me in the door were the "pork belly doughnuts"

Three battered, fried pieces of pork belly with a whiskey/maple glaze. they come three to an order and i had a hard time finishing one.

The concept is amazing. the product could've been executed a little better, but it's a solid little treat.

What got me was the actual sensation of years of my life falling away from me with each bite. As i was eating it, i got the feeling i was doing something i shouldn't be.

It was tasty. 

They also offer some bottomless mimosa business on the weekends.

Nothing personal, but i won't be back. 
The pork belly doughnuts were good but everything else on the menu left too much to be desired.
author: Rex N.

description:
After a yummy meal at Yamo, we stumbled upon this place by way of bingo happening inside! Too bad we missed the bingo but there are boardgames galore that you can borrow & play while drinking / eating. 

I love boardgames so this place had me at that. 

Cool murals outside & paintings inside! 

Will definitely go to this place again after a dinner at Yamo! 


3 stars coz I have yet to sample their sliders :)
author: ASIANDIVAH A.

description:
I love this place!
The brunch and bottomless mimosas are amazing. I had never had chicken and waffles before and now I order it every time I go there. And you can just get one, which is great, because I don't need two. That's too much food. In fact, all of their food is pretty small and affordable. And like the other reviews tell you, your mimosa glass will never be empty.
Cheap beers, takes cards, friendly people and a great back patio. Win win win.
author: Kristin T.

description: Bottomless mimosa for $12 with any food order and I haven't met a slider here I didn't absolutely love - my favorite being the lamb. My bf and I come here often on Saturdays and sit on the amazing back patio, soak up the sun and wait to find the bottom of our cups...and we never do thanks to Kim the mimosa fairy! They also change the beers they have on tap pretty regularly and tend to go for the smaller brews, which is awesome. I'm definitely a fan!!
author: Brenda K.

description:
So far, this place is the closest thing to a personal living room we've found in the Mission.  SUPER unassuming, the Sycamore is a great place to come on a sleepy Sunday afternoon to share a plate of fries and a microbrew over a game of Scrabble.  

Nice outdoor space with long tables; kind of a mini-Zeitgeist without the pretention or the ban on photography.

Great neighborhood space.  Tends to be crowded and the layout isn't great for standing up, so if you're coming with a group I'd advice off-hours to ensure you snag a table.
author: Kristin P.

description:
I heard about Sycamore from a fellow friend who proclaimed "You must try the Makers Mark maple glazed pork belly donut holes!!!!!". After comprehending the name of the meal I was riddled with curiosity. The second we walk in the door my friend ordered these hidden gems in which I speak. They were freaking off the charts delicious. A sweet, salty, savory snack attack. YOU KNOW IT.

They had a magnificent array of tasty drafts. We still had a bit of an appetite so I ordered one of every slider (5 types total, ranging from fish to BLT), all of them were delicious. Also ordered a basket of fries, they disappeared real quick.

There is also a cool assortment of board games to choose from if you go with a group. We grabbed a deck of cards and played some interesting drinking games. The bartender Kathy was super courteous and deserves a 5-bomb!
author: Jason M.

description: The Sycamore is practically an extension of my living room...since I live on Sycamore. But the atmosphere, the bartenders, the music, the food, the great selection of beers and board games make this place far superior to my living room. So I find myself here instead of my living room during the day. This place gets really popular at night and especially the weekends (unlike my living room). I'm a big fan of the fried chicken sliders. Eat them. Do it.
author: Rubeun T.

description: I love coming to the Sycamore for brunch. Even though it can get crowded, the bartenders are friendly and the food is great. I love all of the sliders and the pork belly donuts. The bartenders definitely keep your bottomless mimosas truly bottomless. The back patio is a great place to sit with a group and mingle with other people.
author: Lauren F.

description:
GO HERE FOR BRUNCH. 

A lot of restaurants pretend like the have bottomless mimosas, but The Sycamore has the best bottomless mimosas hands down. This place is so sweet for a Sunday brunch with a ton of friends. 

We went to the sycamore with about 15 people. We sat outside under the gorgeous sun and played cards against humanity all afternoon sipping on mimosas and eating delicious brunch food.

The service was amazing. The servers were so friendly, and the food was delicious.
author: Monica B.

description: The only reason I have hesitated to leave a review here is because this is one of those places you don't want anyone to know about. I love this place SO much. Their staff are the best people in the universe. Their beer. Amazing. Food. Amazing. My go-to is the black bean burger and the mac-n-cheese balls...with bacon, obviously.
author: Rachel T.

description:
I really wanted to give this place a 3.5 stars. It has a nice backyard, which I always find to be key in bars I like. The selection of beers was okay, not great but then again it is a small bar. 

So after a few beers, the table needed a snack so I ordered a basket of fries FOR $5. COME ON $5 for a basket of fries????? That is outrageous. It is not a huge basket of fries either. I also took the time to review their lunch menu. $12 for lunch? Does that seem right? I think they have interesting bar food but are charging way yo much for it. 

Next time I will be back at Zeitgeist ;)
author: Denise L.

description:
What an amazing deal. Endless mimosas for only $12? This is with a minimum purchase of $8 but of course you gotta eat when you sip. 

This place has a very friendly atmosphere. From the chair cushions in the front to the long tables and coffee table in the back this place is meant to get people to converse. YES, realize that there is a HUGE area in the back. Don't be fooled by the emptiness in the front. 

The food is good and there is plenty to select from on the brunch menu. I'd go with the beef sliders/biscuits or the salmon omelette. The pork belly donuts didn't live up to the hype, and they tasted like something fatty and fried. Avoid the vegan sandwich unless you are vegan.

Our waitress is awesome, and unlike at most "endless"places our waitress kept coming over to fill our glasses with more mimosa. That's something to be appreciated as we came with a party of ~20.
author: Jason T.

description:
I've come back two time since my first review and I'm very disappointed to say this is not the same place as it was when it first opened up. 

Food is still the same deliciousness, but the service and atmosphere has changed... both times bartenders were not as friendly and actually this past time I felt like I had to be extremely aggressive in order to get noticed and get my food. I felt like the girl couldn't have cared less about making a sale. 

The bathroom is also way more disgusting than I remembered... probably just because it is just more used now, because more people frequent the place, but still they need to do a better job of cleaning. 

I would probably go back if I were in the area, because of the food, but I will no longer recommend this as a must try place in the mission.
author: Rona Y.

description:
I am surprised that this bar has brunch. I am even more surprised that the brunch is good! Also, there is pretty much no wait, which is amazing.

Must try things:
-Pork belly donuts. Yesss. Tender, delicious pork belly surrounded by a perfectly fried donut. Can I order a dozen of these?
-Bottomless mimosas: They are truly bottomless. My glass never reached the bottom for the two whole hours I was there.
author: Wendy S.

description:
Came here for Sunday brunch:

The food took quite a long time to arrive (around half an hour).

I took the Butter Lettuce salad: it was just a lot of lettuce with a couple of berries, a few pieces of pear and a little bit of cheese. It was rather insipid. 

The bottomless mimosa didn't taste amazing.

My friends' order was completely messed up.

Pros: the backyard / terrace offers a little "oasis of quiet" in the middle of the Mission. That was nice. But beware:it can get really, really hot since there is no wind / current. If it's sunny, make sure you get under an umbrella.

They did a pretty good job at keeping my mimosa refilled. 

In conclusion: I've experienced better. I would try other places before coming here again, and I definitely would order something else, since my salad was definitely a disappointment.
author: Leon S K.

description: I all most want to give them a bad review so people don't find out how amazing it is. My all time favorite brunch spot features bottomless, thats right you heard me, bottomless mimosas for 9.99 and and smoked salmon eggs Benedict that is like none other. The mimosa fairy that floats by and fills your cup will never let it go empty. In fact she informs me that if its never empty it only counts as one drink. Who knew? Also see The Willows, their sister bar in SOMA.
author: Matt H.

description:
pork belly donuts?! you've got to be kidding me, right?!

WRONG! this isn't some concoction i created in my dreamland of swine! this is REAL! 

pork belly fried with donut batter glazed with makers mark maple syrup and sprinkled with sea salt?! typing this description alone not only made my mouth water, but probably semi clogged an artery in the process!

if you're like myself and have an affinity for all things pork belly and whiskey, then you must purchase this delectable treat! for $4, you'll get a trio of this lovely concoction! you can thank me later for it, but be forewarned... a major cardio workout needs to be implemented no more than a day later! your heart and body will thank you for it after devouring this sinful treat :)
author: Coriemae P.

description: Ended up here while bar hopping on my bday! Such a nice place with red walls, an intimate cosy feeling and just nice people with a sense of humour (guy handing out jell-o shots!). The open bench area at the back was comfortable and fun with a random movie screening over our heads, projected against the wall. Not tried the food here yet but will be back :)
author: Malvika B.

description:
The atmosphere was great; we played some Apples to Apples, and took note of the fashionable clientele. Unfortunately the food left a little bit to be desired. I woke up in a hot sweat the previous night in a mood strongly desirous of gravy. But when I acted upon that desire by ordering the biscuits and gravy, the biscuits were quite dry, even though the gravy looked delicious. Another facet of my dream was well spiced lamb, and The Sycamore, again, almost delivered with some juicy but lacking in flavor lamb slider.

This is, of course, neglecting the bottomless mimosas. They're stellar.
author: David S.

description: Food is great!! Bottomless mimosas for lunch, yes please!! Biggest issue is that the patio clearly has a marked non-smoking section, yet one table just started lighting up and not a single employee cares. I am sitting in a haze of cigarette  and pot smoke. Kinda hard to enjoy my food this way.  Been here a bunch of times and always been great, so sorry that the suckage is so high right now.
author: Bethany M.

description: Nice intimate bar with outdoor seating in the back. Great beer selection which includes some rare bottles for sale. Bartender wasn't always great at noticing me, even when the bar was barely active. Other then that, it was great.
author: Kyle K.

description:
LUNGSHAN CLOSED . . .  and, especially forgetting that Mission Street does not open before 11 a.m.-

Plan C = and, what did we order to list on our growing scientific C.T.T. -quest for the perfect slider, quest for the perfect F.C., quest for the perfect "bites" . . .

1.  mac/cheese bites
2.  Fried Chicken

- got the order al fresco so oso very fast, and thinking I had ordered fried chicken & thought the little slider that came with the perfect little mac/cheese bites was a free-B CATFISH slider . . .  Alas, when I confronted the cook to ask the progress of the f.c. (after about 25 min. soaking up rays [SHIRT off] the back patio all to myself).  He tells me that the slider WAS the fried chicken.  .  .
. . .  Do I know the difference between fried chicken & fried fish? . . .  $12.50 (with 1/2 1/2 lemonade iced T).

I'm feeling UN settled &  UN settisfeld.  I have to peruse the menus AGAIN!

Nonttheless tasty & crunchy crunchy crunchy!
author: Clifford L.

description: "Wheelchair accessible" only partly; you can ask to be let in to the patio area around the back, although they may need to move some kegs out of the way, and the loo isn't accessible, which makes it difficult to enjoy all that beer. That said, the service was impeccable, the tap selection lovely, the food tasty, and the spirit of community is strong among the Burner-hippie-artsy crowd that makes this their local. If you like sitting out on the patio at Zeitgeist but want a little variety or some somewhat hipper snacks, get to the Sycamore. If you want a slightly more wheel-acessible option, try the Willows, which is its sister pub without a patio but with an indoors I can get into on cold foggy nights.
author: Anne K.

description:
Slid into a table out back with friends and then sent some sliders sliding into mah belly. 

The fried chicken slider was my favorite, although the BLT with heirloom tomato was nothing to scoff at either. Thought the catfish slider was a bit greasy.

Liked the vibe out back: no wait, super casual and they had The Good, The Bad, and The Ugly projecting onto the wall behind us.

If you find your self slip-sliding around the neighborhood with an empty tummy, you'll find heading here won't be a slip-up.
author: Pants P.

description:
Really small space. Capacity 49. Patio w more midday than afternoon sun

Orangey sangria. Pork belly doughnuts. Tiny but delicious sliders- catfish and fried chicken. Board games. Friendly casual vibe. Board games inside!
author: Nors P.

description: The Sycamore is a great, hipsta-fied (I think I'm going to trademark this expression) bar with a wide selection of beer and decent food.  The pork belly donuts are exactly what you'd expect them to be - greasy, delicious meat donuts.  We also had a pulled pork sandwich and the mix and match sliders, which weren't that impressive.  The Sycamore is a essentially a smaller version of Zeitgeist with a more relaxed atmosphere.  There is an outdoor area, although it's mostly covered so the smoke can get a bit overhwhelming.  They have board games, but when I was there most seemed to be missing pieces - although I did dominate my friend in Scrabble.  I'm glad this bar is in my neighborhood because I can drop in when I'm looking for a casual drink, and skip it when it looks too crowded.
author: Rachel A.

description: I joined some friends for brunch recently and was not impressed with this place except for the bottomless mimosas, of course. The place is very small and narrow and it took over an hour to get our food which was mediocre and slightly overpriced. There are a lot of great restaurants in the city for brunch in the city that you can avoid this one. Go for some drinks instead.
author: Christian B.

description:
In keeping with our trend of visiting the vast and varied beer bars highlighted in the Northern California Craft Beer Guide, we stopped into the Sycamore.  Little did we know what a gem was awaiting us.

Despite having a handful of taps, this is one of the most progressive and daring beer bars in town.  Instead of the usual suspects, we were treated to local craft beers that we had never even heard of ... Even from trips to the actual brewery.  Gotta say, if you can get a one-off from Bear Republic, you rate big time in my books.  That dark ale was killer!  The bottle offerings were just as impressive ...and I am scared to say this in print ...but also affordable.  Did I just write that?  I hope I haven't given away the milk AND the cow.

Rumor has it they also have a great Sunday brunch.

Staff is wonderfully fun and chatty.  Will go here again and again.
author: Joe W.

description:
We came here yesterday after spending hours at Dolores Park. We were starving and went here upon recommendation.

There was hardly anyone when we arrived, which was great because we practically had the whole front room to ourselves:

The Sliders we ordered were (drum roll, please):

- Catfish Slider
- Beef Slider
- Lamb Slider
- Fried Chicken Slider

I honestly can't tell you which one was my favorite, as they each were absolutely delicious. 

Add these sliders in with a Crispin Cider and a game of Scrabble (courtesy of The Sycamore), and we had the perfect Labor Day! I'd definitely come here again with friends.
author: Christine C.

description:
3.25/5 outdoor yay

i love the outdoor area. i think it's a nice escape from the rest of the mission, and it's a cool place to catch a beer and just chill with folks. they serve food, but sometimes it comes out so slow, so i'd say stick to the drinks.
author: Alvin D.

description:
New place in my hood for drinks & good food, excellent!

The bad news: 
1. Only beer and wine.  While they have taps for 20+ beers they only have 7 or so.  
2. No non-boozie drinks (not even ginger beer)
3. The food sucked.   The ingredients appeared fresh and delicious but the salad was an oil slick and the $8 mushrooms we so salty that we left them over.  In fact, we all left the place hungry and with our ears ringing from the noise.  

2 stars for Connect Four.
author: Miriam S.

description: Great beer, pork dougnuts, and a atmosphere with character...  what more do you need?!
author: William B.

description:
~AVERAGE FOOD, DISRESPECTFUL STAFF~

I don't yelp, but I use the app often when searching for places to eat. I dislike reviewing places because I have a terrible memory when it comes to food and I can't stand taking pictures of food while it's sitting right in front of me, just begging to be eaten. But I feel obligated to write a review of The Sycamore after my experience.

After looking for a place for brunch in the Mission, my GF and I felt that Sycamore would be a nice place to sit down and relax. I ordered the black bean burger (I wanted the pork sandwich, but they ran out, that's fine though) my GF had the Roast Beef sandwich and we ordered the pork belly donuts for apps.

Food:

Pork Belly Donuts - I love donuts, I love pork. This sounds like a match made in heaven, but to both of our disappointment, they were bland and had a weird bitter aftertaste.
Black Bean Burger - I loved it, my GF hated it.
Roast beef sandwich - Average

Okay, so I would probably rate this place a 3, went on with life and have the mediocre food vanish from my memory forever. But two incidents happened that really blackened our experience here. First, my GF went to use the restroom after we ate. While she was waiting, one of the butch looking waitresses (owner?) told my GF in a condescending tone that the "restroom was for customers only." My GF replied that she WAS a customer and the waitress looked at my GF and walked off. Later, she came and told my GF "my apologies." Why would she assume that my GF was not a customer? The only thing that stood out in my mind was that we were the only Asians in the restaurant. I don't want to assume anything because SF is such a diverse and welcoming City, but I have no idea why the waitress would assume she wasn't a customer. We were both sitting RIGHT IN FRONT of the staff in plain view. For the sake of not playing the "race card" I'll just assume the waitress had one too many mimosas.

The second incident happened when I went to pay the bill. I had to wait nearly 15 minutes to get someone to help me and when they did, I discovered that they tacked on some Granola that I did not order. I told one of the bartender/waitresses that about the mistake and she stared at me, gave me a hostile face and told me "Are you sure?? You told me you wanted Granola." I had no idea what she was talking about, this one definitely had one too many drinks. She agreed to credit me back, but her bad attitude was just too much. I was glad to leave The Sycamore.  

I will NOT be coming back to this establishment.
author: Kevin C.

description:
i thought it was alright bro, i got the pork belly donuts, and the four sliders. sliders 3:50 and i got 1dollar side of fries, pork belly 3 for 4 dollars. It was pretty expensive for the amount of food. I just wanted to try it so i ate with my cousin. I think half a slider you dont get the full amount of flavor. We got the beer battered fish, beef, lamb, and the fried chicken slider.

 I thought the lamb was the best, tasted really good, you can taste the meat, i like the burgers though, it was like oozing oil lol, i liked that. the fries were pretty good, really crispy. the fried chicken had sour cabbages i think masked the flavor. beef like had no sauce bro, was my least favorite. my cousin liked the beer batted fish the best. It was pretty cool, friendly pretty blonde waiter ^^, and there were board games on a shelf, like A LOT of games to play with lol. i lost to my cousin on Othello,

 The pork belly donuts, was alright, like the outer golden crisper sweetness was good, but i didn't know pork belly was just what i eat all the thing, cause i'm chinese i eat what we call 5 layer pork meat. tasted and looked exactly like it, but one of them had  way more meat. overall it was a good experience, like i wanna try new food in life, i thought it was alright. sliders too small for me bro
author: David L.

description:
joined some friends here and sat out back on the patio. 

definitely preferred the back over the inside and it feels way dingy inside. 
there are tons of board games but not much space to play in the back. 

also, you have to order drinks at the bar which is strange..it'd be nice to be able to order from the waiter so i don't have to get up and nudge people around
author: Janet Y.

description:
A friend from the east coast was in town and wanted some "regular food," so I took him here. Who doesn't love drinking beer outside in the San Francisco summer?

It was a pretty good experience. I had the really tasted BBQ seitan sandwich ($8 and you have to pay extra for fries). My friend has some sliders. We split the artichoke hearts, which were just so-so. The french fries are perfect. I wish there was more going on with the menu for vegetarians, but i have to say that seitan sandwich is solid.The service is friendly. I have no major complaints, although, what's missing?

Were my expectations just too high? I can't put my finger on it it, but this place is lacking something special. Food was tasty, price was right, the beer garden's cool, and best of all there is no crowd here. It's a no-muss, no-fuss fancy bar food situation. Still, it's worth another visit, so I'll probably keep The Sycamore in my backpocket and maybe re-categorize it as a lunch-only spot.
author: Stumbalina b.

description: I'm sure there are other places you can go in San Francisco that have bottomless mimosas with decent food and better service. My friends and I are visiting San Francisco and were told this place is good for bottomless mimosa brunch. While the price for bottomless mimosas is good, $14 with $8 food order, the rude service is just not worth it. We ordered the breakfast chicken slider, fried egg slider, lamb burger slider, chicken and waffles, and pork belly donuts. The food was good for the price, the portions were somewhat small, but ok for the price. You have to order everything at the bar, including food. They were taking a long time to come around with more mimosas so I went to the bar to get more, considering everything is ordered at the bar I thought this would be ok. The sever rudely said to me, "you know what if you would just have a seat she'll come around she has a lot of people to serve". I wish I could say this was the only person that was rude but the entire staff were not friendly. Maybe locals are use to this kind of service from this establishment. The seating is also very awkward. If you're visiting San Francisco choose another restaurant if you're looking for bottomless mimosas, it will be worth it to pay a little more.
author: Treva D.

description:
Thought the roast beef sandwich was super disappointing. I could not chew through the stringy slices of beef, so each bite left me with meat hanging from my lips like a sloppy dog. Embarrassing! And the sesame seed soft hamburger bun had a slight chemical taste. I only got sauce, no mayo, so perhaps there weren't enough artificial flavors to balance out. 

Still, the place had a great vibe. The little patio in the back is an oasis, and the crunchy fries were great.
author: Carolyn F.

description:
There is little, if anything bad to say about the Sycamore...

I took my friends there after reading a review of it in The Weekly Yelp and man, did this place deliver!

We got there around 8pm on a Wednesday, and the place was already packed... we had hopes of sitting out on the back patio, but ended up snagging a table in the main bar area a few mins after we walked in.  In true me fashion, I had already scoped out the menu ahead of time, and my mouth was watering just thinking about those little burgers that I was going to do some work on.

The sliders were out of this world and even though we ordered a plethora of the little guys, we had to order a 2nd round!  While all of them were amazing, the catfish and lamb burger.. Oh. My. God.

The only downside of the place is it's size. Because of its size, finding a place to sit can be tricky.  Also, I am not sure if it just happened to be the night that we went on, but it took a good 45 mins to get our food...  luckily, they have my favorite beer on tap PranQster Ale ::mmm PranQster:: so I happily drank the time away (i.e. I can't complain :)

All-in-all a very delicious, lively and popular joint -- check it out when you have a chance.

 I can't wait to hit this place up for brunch and try their Pork Belly Donuts!
author: Alyssa S.

description:
This chill bar settled in the armpit of 16th mission area is super chill. A selection of beers rarely found elsewhere gives the impression well though curation without the slight air pretense you find at Tornado. Folks at the Sycamore attempt chill. Then again a four person bar breeds conversation. Guess that's I like about Sycamore. It's intimate yet platonic. 

Outdoor seating is very nice and their food is pretty awesome. I remember the lane sliders being deceptively filling and succulent. 

Sycamore truly offers something unique.
author: Quentin J.

description:
I write this rave review with reluctance, as I pray this place stays happily in thriving business, but I fear it becoming overrun with hipsting brunchers a la Boogaloo.

Food: nice variety and quality--some things could use salt, but that's just me and I oversalt everything.  I've had the carnitas benedict (on sopas!) and the biscuits and gravy.  Comfort food max.

Bottomless mimosas--YES!  And truly bottomless, unlike some stingy places (that's you, Heart).  They just keep coming.  One of the delightful waitstaff once quipped winkily, "If it never hits the bottom, you've only had one."  I.  am.  in.  love.

Awesome quaint little back patio in a city with sparse outdoor drinking opportunities.

This place seems oddly (luckily?) undiscovered and therefore uncrowded and therefore soooo relaxed...

I hope it stays so.
author: Kennau K.

description:
Bottomless mimosas. Pork belly donuts. Fried chicken sliders. 

Need I say more? Ok I will.

Casual. Outdoor benches. Perfect Sunday with friends.

Try it! I can't wait to go back.
author: Deann M.

description: jenn is amazing!! "the domer" - she kept us happy and our glasses full!! love this place!!!
author: Jay M.

description:
Sliders were....small. I would need at least 5 to fill me up. 

Pork belly donuts tastes exactly how they sound. 

Good atmosphere. Packed tues evening.  Bar stools too low for bar. I felt like a kid sitting at the 'adult' table.
author: Paran Y.

description: Fun spot to meet friends, with good energy, interesting wine and beer choices, and tasty sliders for a very reasonable price.  The roast beef sandwich/slider was outstanding... Will definitely come back.  Didn't get to visit the patio or have the "donuts" yet, but need to!
author: Nancy E.

description: Was visiting SF for the weekend and a native friend brought us here so we could start out day rage. Bottomless mimosas were ordered and refills came often. Got the pork belly doughnuts, were good but not what I was expecting at all. Also had some sliders, which I found to be only mediocre. Cool vibes and the place is a lil small but there is outdoor seating available in the back. Was caught playing drinking games with the mimosas.. Shame on me.
author: Andy H.

description: Love this bar! Not only do they have a kick ass beer selection and a cozy, casual atmosphere--but the bites of food are great too. Don't miss out on their tortilla chips, they're homemade.
author: Marit S.

description: Went there for lunch with a coworker after reading the reviews. The sycamore have the best sliders with a very reasonable price. Each of us had 3 different sliders. The tilapia and the fried chicken ones I got were great. There's no rich mayo in the slaw in the fried chicken slider. My favorite is the lamb slider. Juicy, tender and full of flavor! My coworker said the classic beef and the BLT were both great too. Will definitely go back.
author: Cheryl X.

description:
This bar claims to be "Your new favorite bar in the Mission." This is a bold statement. Thank goodness it's true--for me, anyway.

Until now I've only BARTed to the Mission for Mexican food (http://www.yelp.com/bi...) and maple glazed bacon apple donuts (http://www.yelp.com/bi...). Now I have another reason and it's more than just a tree.

At the moment I'm writing this the Sycamore has 24 beers: 8 on tap, 12 bottled, and 4 canned. While the Sycamore has far fewer  beers than the Monk's Kettle (http://www.yelp.com/bi...), the beers are cheaper, food better, and wi-fi available. What more could a thirsty, hungry, e-mail-fixated person want?

My friend Amber L. and I had the pork belly donuts, which were greasy spoon turned into god's spoon with the maple Makers Mark glaze. Why are they so savory, sweet, and scrumptious, yet so small? I could eat about nine of these before my pores have an oil spill.

The sliders are also worth writing about. All four were winners. I had the fried chicken slider and the beer-battered rock cod slider, each of which was a wondrous three bites. The rock cod was unfortunately bland after the flavor-packed pork belly donuts and fried chicken--I'll make a note to devour this first next time. Amber L. really liked both the lamb and beef sliders. 

I'll be back for in the Mission soon for (Syca)more. Love gastropubs!
author: Liz T.

description:
ohhh The Sycamore, you and your pork belly donuts and mac&cheese balls. I don't know any other place in the city that makes mac&cheese balls. If you do, pls holler!

Their chef Allie is fabulous. Bc I've found their bar food just oh so yummy in my tummy  (it's just really good bar food) I've catered from here twice. Both times a hit with the crowd. Their sliders are decent. Their main attraction is the pork belly donuts. ATTN: eat when it's hot (aka don't get it to go, it gets soggy and cold, not the same!) 

I hear they have bottomless mimosas for Sunday brunches! Perfect. I'll go Saturday night and again Sunday afternoon :)
author: Rosa L.

description:
PORK BELLY DONUTS. That is all.

(Okay, fine. A real review?)

Small but oft-varied selection of brews and wines.

Great food (though I have yet to try brunch). Several different kinds of sliders, all delicious. Solid salads. And the positively bomb-diggity aforementioned pork belly donuts with bourbon maple syrup.

Crowd is chill, music is good, and the back patio is nice if it's not too cold out.
author: Sam K.

description:
Dudes -- this is probably the last bar in the Mission where you can actually have a conversation. 

Also, they're open for lunch on weekdays, and for those of you who don't live in the Mission (which is a lot of you people who come party here, I've noticed), there aren't that many places that actually ARE. Open for lunch on weekdays. Seriously. 

They have good beer, and board games, and some food I can't eat, and it's cozy 'cause it's small and has dark walls and sure, there's a dank concrete San Francisco "patio" out back, but mostly this place is cool because:

1. As stated, you can have a conversation in it.

2. There are actually people working and hanging out there worth having conversations with (perhaps even rarer than a chill bar). 

Go check it out before something spoils either of these.
author: Lisa T.

description: Love this place! They have great beers and fun games to play while your there. The outdoor patio is always full but always double check because it is worth sitting outside.
author: Maria C.

description: I don't really write reviews but this place was awesome. We had bottomless mimosas (no brainer), chicken and waffles (really good), roast beef sandwich (little spicy kick which was great), and biscuits and gravy with 2 fried eggs (really good). It's small and only have beer and wine but the workers here are amazing.
author: Jonathan O.

description: Pork Belly Donuts... Bravo. A small serving of them, but the price was right! Respectable beers on tap, too. Will return!
author: Lizzie C.

description:
I wish I could make this font bigger, but have to just have to say... 

PORK BELLY DONUTS, YUM.

Remember the commercials about Australian Toaster Biscuts (not Thomas English Muffins.)? Sycamore Pork Belly Donuts make my mouth water!

So these "donuts" aren't really donuts. They are basically a piece of braised pork belly battered and deep fried with a generous maple glaze and a sprinkle of sea salt. All I can say about these things is that all you have to do is try one and you'll be addicted. That's all I have to say about that. 

As for other the other fare at Sycamore, I tried the lamb slider, fried fish slider, cobb salad, and an order of fries. Both sliders were well seasoned and there was a generous portion of meat, a very good meat to bread ratio. The fries were average, but the cobb salad was disappointing. The cobb salad just didnt have enough blue cheese!! It had plenty of everything else like bacon, but it just needed more cheese!!!


Overall the Sycamore has some decent food, but the pork belly donuts really won me over, I think i went twice in 2 day!!!

Oh yeah they have a good selection of beer.
author: Jeff C.

description:
After hearing about their pork belly donuts, awesome brunch menu and bottomless mimosas, we decided to go to the Sycamore on Saturday for brunch. 

The place is pretty small with a patio in the back. Everything on the menu looked delicious. We decided to go for the 4$ for 3 pork belly donuts (YUMMMM!) and 1 of each of the sliders with fries. 

We were 3 to share this order and all 3 of us were pretty happy after that.

The food tend to be on the heavy side. If you want a light brunch then do not go there!

We enjoyed our experience there and will definitely go back :D
author: Vickie Z.

description: Been here while out with friends a couple times, chill spot. Not much of a beer guy but if you are they have an impressive selection of microbrews. Never tried the food. It has a patio out back so it never feels cramped, real nice bartenders.
author: Kevin C.

description:
The devil's in the details.

Came here last night with a few girlfriends and we had a great evening. The beer and the food were pretty impressive, There were a few things that were sort of off though. I feel like this place could be seriously awesome if they just fixed a few things. 

Pros:
Small, but good, beer selection.
Well-priced, good quality, inventive food.
Back patio
Good juke box music

Cons:
Music was way too loud.
The front of the restaurant slopes downward, making sitting uncomfortable and causing drinks to slide off the table (seriously)
Tables were all wobbly/off-center, also causing spilled beverages.
Clientele includes some douche bag hipsters, including this guy that claimed we cut in front of him in line when he clearly wasn't standing there when we walked up. 
No table service/hard to order at bar.
Smells a little of mold.
Mulled wine was sub par.

I'm sure I'll go back because despite those things I had a good time, and what's really important is the quality of the drink and the food, but I dont' think The Sycamore will earn a higher rating until they pay attention to the details.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Weekend brunch is amazing.  Get the chicken and waffles.  If you decide you want to stop drinking your bottomless mimosa before 3pm, you're going to have to be assertive about it, because the servers don't give up easy.

Also great at night.  Not too loud and there's always space.
author: Mark S.

description: The food was great! I'm from the south, so chicken and waffles and my chicken slider tasted like home. The bottomless deal is great also.  You should come join the fun!
author: Evan R.

description:
I LOVE this place. It's got great everything. I like their wonderful selection of beers, their delicious selections of food, the bingo night, the great outdoor patio, all the fun art on the walls, and more.

If you like this place and you want a full bar, check out the willows. You trade out the patio for a pool table and a full bar.
author: Kelly J.

description:
Man-o-man I cannot wait to come back to this place! It's an awesome little hole in the wall (literally) that has yummy comfort food and a great beer selection, both bottles and tapped.

I came here during lunch time and it was empty, which I consider a good thing since this place is so tiny it would fill up quick on a busy night. 

Get the pork belly doughnuts and the fried cheese!
author: Jasmin H.

description: As a bar it has good selection. They have bottles for sale of a few rarer beers, but expect a premium. They have an outdoor area that is covered but not particularly water proof.
author: Will D.

description:
Soooo... the pork belly donuts with Maker's Mark-maple glaze. The fuss is entirely warranted over these babies. After sampling a half of one, (I would have gobbled them all up if they weren't being shared by the table,) I experienced what could only be explained as a porkgasm. Anthony Bourdain would have approved.

The patio was a bit claustrophobic with it's concrete and high walls, and general lack of decor but our server was attentive and super nice/cool. The music was mostly classic punk and alt standards.  I'll definitely be back to try more food. I was with a big group of people, later at night but I bet it's a great date spot.

I must mention my affinity for the bar's name because it reminds me of a notorious 'hood in my hometown.
author: Nomi G.

description:
This place is just ok. Tried four out of the five sliders. Lamb and cow sliders were the best in my opinion. 

The chicken and catfish sliders weren't all that. $3.50 per slider is little overpriced i think for seriously the tiniest sliders I've ever had. $2.50 seems about right. But whatever its a dollar so who cares?

I also ordered there famous (i don't know who says its famous other than them) roast beef sando. I honestly was expecting something more than a sloppy, messy, overly sauced up bunch of roast beef and nothing else with it. Kinda reminded me of an Arby's sando. Bread was warm, meat was not and drowning in super sweet bbq sauce. 

The side salad was fresh, the 6 french fries I got were whatever. There is a good selection of draft beers and a patio. I wouldn't go out of my way to eat here. If your standing on the corner and want a quick bite this is a good spot.
author: Ethan S.

description:
It's a very chill bar - not fancy, not dirty... just a little semi-dive-ish bar in the Mission.  If you know the area, great.  If you don't, The Sycamore is right in between 17th and 18th on Mission, so some people hanging outside the bar can be somewhat ghetto, but harmless.  I did lock up my bike outside and looked over to make sure it was still there.  No problemo. 

Pro's: 
- Fatty pice of pork belly, deep fried in dough.  Yummy, but like many other people said in their reviews, you can probably only eat one b/c it's super greasy & fatty.  When I think about it now, it grosses me out, but it was delicious when I was eating it. : P 
- Beer selection was good.  Between the four of us, we covered 4 shades/types of beer.
- Board games!!  Taboo, Scrabble, Apples to Apples.... they even have a Ouija board... eek. I won't be touching that one, ever.  
- Chill atmosphere
- Two dudes playing guitar in the corner

Con's:
- Say no on sangria.  Well, I do realize that this is probably a rarity, but I might've gotten food poisoning of some sort from here.  I can only think of sangria that could've caused it because between the four of us, we shared the donuts and fries - and I was the only one, who chose to try the sangria and ate most of the fruits inside it.  Nobody else had a reaction except for me, so I blame the sangria/fruits for waking me up nauseated at 4am with a massive stomach ache.  
- Two dudes playing guitar in the corner. I liked it... and they were good, don't get me wrong, but when they started singing... well, let's just say that I was kinda relieved when they were done. 

Anyway, the bottom line - I would give it 3.5 stars, but I don't care what kind of a goddess it is - the Toilet Goddess is not cool.  I'll be back here again, but I'll definitely skip the sangria next time.
author: Catherine H.

description: I attended a San Francisco Beer Week 2014 event here. I came for Saison Night and enjoyed many a glass of beer.  I also had a few of the sliders (Chicken and Tilapia). I was surprised to have a poultry and fish option for sliders. Nom! I thought the wait staff were firm and friendly. I wish I had of taken a photo of the beer tap sculpture on the ceiling above the bar but next time. I am coming back for the donuts they ran out of also.
author: Infodiva B.

description: Nice tap selection, nice roast beef sandwich. And, for brunch, I love how the server walks around with pitchers of mimosas, as other servers would with water or iced tea. Win.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
YES!

Way to bounce back from a shotty first experience!

Came here last Saturday and had brunch again with my boyfriend and a friend who is celebrating a short vacation. I had the French Toast on banana oatmeal with Whiskey-Infused syrup. YES! It was SUCH a win. Who would have thought to lay french toast on a bed of oatmeal? AWESOME.

Obviously, we all went in for the bottomless mimosa deal, and they just kept on coming.

During our brunch session, we took the time to dive into their selection of board games, which was a great spin on our usual brunch routine. It really made the vibe even cooler. Also, we took advantage of the outside patio again, which is still pretty awesome.

This time I had the pork belly donuts and was able to appreciate them to the fullest and they were PHENOMENAL. So good.

I'm glad I came back again, I'm now a die-hard fan.
author: Trav M.

description:
I remember when this place was an awesome rock-and-roll sushi place. This is not that place.

It is a great neighborhood bar with a good beer selection, board games to play, and decent food.

I love pork belly. And I can't recommend their donuts; otherwise, if you're in the area, check it out.
author: Joshua C.

description:
I really like it here. There isn't much mid-range stuff to do in the Mission (i.e., you have Foreign Cinema or a taqueria, but not much in between), so I'm glad to see so many places like this opening up lately.

I've been here twice already. We pigged out on the A-plus sliders both times (they're all delicious) and relaxed with wine and beer. It gets pretty crowded and I don't think I'd like it nearly as much if I had to stand. Some board games available, too, though Trivial Pursuit will make you feel dumb and Sorry will make you feel 5. Nonetheless, I'm definitely making it a regular spot if I feel like a drink after work or something mellow and close by.

Banksy (on the Sycamore side) a plus!
author: Tara R.

description: Love it. Has a nice crew working here, they have board games, a friendly crowd, good music selection, a back porch where smokers rejoice, regular folk, lots of interesting beers and good food. They even have free Wi-Fi and outlets for charging on the wall.   My only critique is that it needs to be a little cleaner to be a great spot.  Had a great time!
author: keith g.

description:
I love this place.  I love their food.  I love their beers.  I love this place.

Ok, now let me expand.

Their pork belly donut is incredibly effing good.  Their beef sliders melts in my mouth.  Their pork belly sandwich is also really good.  

I went once when they were offering the Red and White beer by Dogfish Head, so damn good.

They offer scrabble and bottomless mimosas on Sunday.

I think I can go on and on about this place but all you need to know is I want you to go there even though I don't really want you to go there because it's busy enough for one to notice this place must be the shit but not too busy where you don't want to go anymore because it's too damn crowded.

I love you Sycamore!
author: Mabel L.

description:
I didn't get what yelp meant by saying the ambience is "hipster" until I stepped in the place.

If an unknown indie band, (who would get big one day, and a certain american apparel wearing group of people would say: "I used to listen to them before they got big")  were to shoot a music video and include a bar scene, Sycamore would be that bar. 

Its a neat place with a wooden look to it and a jukebox  with...rock? (super generalized term) songs spanning from the late 80s to the 90s.

The crowd is pretty hipster too, the table next to us seriously looked like a typical group with their hoodies, messenger bags, skinny pants, etc.  

My friend was getting pretty drunk over the mimosas, and couldn't remember the lyrics to a 3OH3! song and was like: "shush girl, and shut your lips...shit i forgot the last line,"  and someone from the hipster table rudely/coolly remarked, "uh...i think it's do the helen keller and talk with your hips." I just thought to myself: "yeah, you would know that hipster."

(btw i have nothing against hipsters, I just found it funny that a restaurants ambiance could be considered hipster, just commenting on the "hipster ambiance =P)

For some reason I was stupid and didnt' read a yelp review before I went and ordered a smoked salmon benedict, cuz I really wanted a benedict that day. 

 It was okay, but was a little pricey when adding their pork belly donuts and bottomless mimosas (expensive $29 brunch)  And after reading some reviews on yelp, you should definitely ONLY go for the sliders and pork belly donuts, or else you wont be too happy and have dropped alot of money like me :(

The sliders my friends ordered did look good, and were at a decent $3.50 from what i remember for lamb =P

The staff was really nice about my boisterous table full of silly college kids getting drunk off mimosas at noon. They would just joke around with us and make fun of my friend who was stumbling around.

The bottomless mimosas were pretty much bottomless, the mimosa maker kept up with us and never let us reach an empty glass, unless we chugged it when we saw her come over =P

There's a solid collection board games too that you can chill with :)
author: Devon J.

description:
Any time you put the words "Fried," "Mac-n-cheese" and "bacon" together on the menu you are doing something great. This was a great place to go for happy hour and they have a great selection of beers on tap. My friends and I had a good time.

The only knock I have is that the smoke from people smoking in the back made its way into the bar area which was annoying.
author: Marty W.

description: We came here from drinks one night and it was very good. The back patio area was cool and they play movies on the wall sometimes. Our drinks were quality and the prices were not crazy so quality place as far as I am concerned!
author: Madison O.

description:
I hesitate to tell you how awesome this place is because it might make it hard to get a table :-P

That said, do NOT hesitate to get the pork belly donuts. Heavens above they will be the best thing you ever put into your mouth for the rest of your life.

Mama~!

Anyway, small but fabulous beer selection, bottomless mimosas of a sunday brunch, the pulled pork sandwich will make you wanna pull on your naughty bits with pleasure, and I can't say enough good about this place.

Also, the co-owner Tim is a delight at the bar.

They're starting to put out an outstanding lunch menu during the week. Go check it out!

Or rather. *cough* Don't go. Really. More room for me =D
author: SisterMable S.

description:
We only stopped in for a beer with no plans to eat but couldn't resist the fried provolone with chimichurri and roasted garlic. Thank you, Sycamore, for introducing me to the wonders of this dish. It was a perfect accompaniment to our London Porters.

Fairly priced, limited but notable draft beer selection, and everything on the menu sounded so delicious we WILL be back for a full sampling of as many dishes we can eat in one sitting!
author: Emily C.

description:
Me and the hubster went for brunch a week ago.  It was an odd experience.  We had not been in before so didn't know the ropes and were left hanging for some time before being recognized.

We sat on the patio which many yelpers have described warmly.  It was anything but.  Four picnic tables amid empty soda machine canisters and an overflowing trash can do not pleasant make.  I realize patios are rare in SF but common folks ... this one has quite a ways to go before reaching "nice".  As in someone would have to make an effort, like some plants and paint and a fenced area to hide the used containers and trash.  

The food was ok but only just ok.  The bloody murdy's were nice.  We were told they were bottomless, but a lack of service saw we only had one each.  Don't know if it was a bad day at Sycamore but we weren't enthralled.
author: Russell D.

description:
The fries can stand alone but if you ask for aoili sauce on the side, you might faint.  Worth the $1 for a handful.

I also tried the pork belly donuts this time around and it was worth the 30 minutes shaved off my life.  It was fatty and greasy and oh so yummy.
author: Ashley I.

description:
Now I love me some asshole bartenders, but I can't stand bad bartenders.  

If I tell you that you, "actually that guy is next, not me," and that guy is the only other person waiting for service, please remember me.

If new people walk up on either side of the guy, please try to remember me.  Please please don't serve BOTH of them before looking my way.

If you finally come over to me, don't look so surprised.

--

Otherwise this place is totally awesome.  I come here pretty frequently and do love it, good food (minimal veggie options), good beers, great patio and GAMES!  

I'm sure I'll rereview in the future and shoot it up to 5 stars.  Y'all just gotta up your service game a couple notches.
author: Mat K.

description:
Came here on a weekday for lunch.  The sliders were delicious!!!!  Got the lamb and ground beef sliders with a side of salad.  Juicy burger.  Had some sweet sangria to wash them down.  Spectacular.  

The pictures gave me the illusion that this was going to be a classy lounge with the red walls and zebra pillows.  But, it was definitely more of the casual bar mission feel to it inside.  There's a nice open patio in the back if it happens to be nice that day.  

Luckily, I was able to find a non-metered parking space so we were able to enjoy our afternoon without watching the clock.  But, it's better to be prepared and just have a handy meter card with you or some quarters
author: stephanie c.

description:
08.11.2010

Cozy space (bar seats six in addition to their six tables), zebra striped pillows, red walls & red velvet curtains & mc escher-esque sketches on the (Sidenote: one of the artists was sitting at the table next to us working on his latest creation.) The Sycamore's atmosphere is completely relaxed & casual--a meeting place for besties & where strangers easily become friends. 

We placed our order at the bar & I noticed the beer list is impressive & well priced. I'm not really a beer drinker (unless it's a corona) but if I were, The Sycamore would be my little piece of beer heaven. Maybe it can be yours. 

We ordered:
* roast beef sandwich for the bf (which I didn't try b/c it was medium rare; the bf really enjoyed it.) Thinly sliced w/ a side of mayo & au jus. 
* mushroom appetizer w/ crostinis: basically a huge bowl of seasonal mushrooms w/ garlic, butter, thyme & sherry. The first few bites are good, but it is a huge portion & I grew tired of the flavor very quickly. 
* $3 sliders: ground beef w/ caramelized onions, blue cheese & garlic aioli (tangy & juicy) & fried chicken (just get it!) with a side of crispy, yummy fries. 
* a coke & a corona
* total: $29

I'll be back to have my corona, fries & sliders on their back patio while the weather is still "warm."
author: Fancypants X.

description:
I walked by this place millions of times. From Prague to the Sycamore, it always had this look like no one ever cleaned it. It's the kind of spot you'd probably not take your mom to, but then again, you should. This is more SF than those lousy places downtown.

I tell you, the sliders were great. It was so hot so we ate at the patio and out food was perfect. I saw a girl come in with her dogs, she looked like one of those kids on Haight but didn't stink. She was offered a bown of water for her dogs. Mixed crowd or what? We then talked to the bartender about beer names. I already like this place.
author: Alexia R.

description:
On the one hand, I think California's definition of a gastropub is significantly different than this Bostonian's.  On the other hand, the Sycamore's sliders are so delicious that I really don't care.

This is a tiny, kind of divey (but hygienic) spot with ample outdoor seating through the back, a bevy of "regulars" and a good selection of well-priced drinks (including a good draught selection).  The catfish sliders are TO DIE FOR, and the lamb sliders are nothing to turn your nose up at either.  The fries, however, are only so-so and could benefit from a little less time in the fryolator.

All told, I deeply enjoy a weeknight evening at the Syc and think you should too.
author: Jillian Y.

description:
Stopped in the Sycamore a few nights ago.

They clearly are going with the dark, dive-bar decor and vibe.  The walls are dark red and I think everything else was black.  S'cool - nothing wrong with that even if it is super-played out.

However, this is no dive bar.  As I ordered my beer the first thing I thought is "what is with the deal with the cost of draft beers being $6 or more?"  It is not like we are in an inflationary period right now.  To add insult to injury, some of the beers are served in smaller, fancy glasses - so, more expensive, less quantity.  I made sure to order my third beer in whatever kind came in a proper pint glass.

[edit]

We tried a couple sandwiches.  I ordered their "famous roast beef" with both mayonnaise and BBQ sauce.  Wasn't awful but was a bit bland.  Needed some onions or a better sauce.  It was like eating a luke-warm stack of roast beef on a bun.  My friend ordered a seitan sandwich.  She enjoyed it.  I took a bite and it actually was flavorful and hot.

Overall, the place is small.  I would hate to be here if it ever was crowded as the bar is teeeny and it seemed the single bartender was overwhelmed with the moderate number of people present when I was there.

The back patio is lackluster.  A few folding chairs, some thrift store furniture, some dying plants.  *yawn* 

I don't see any reason to stop back here.  Not a single one.  I don't hate the place bit with so so many other gastropubs (haha!), I mean bars, to visit in SF, why go to a lame one?
author: Jude G.

description:
It was one of those mornings where nothing seems to go right.  Remembered The Sycamore and decided to head there for lunch.  Upon arriving, it was hard to imagine that this great little place is barely two weeks old.  In that short time, it has already settled in and carved out a nice little niche for itself on Mission near 17th.

The owner, Tim (Tym?), was really cool and I had a fun time talking with him at the bar while waiting for my lunch.  I ordered the North Shore (Boston) roast beef sandwich (asked for no mayo) and a side of fries along with a glass of Ancient Peaks cabernet sauvignon.  I enjoyed my roast beef and loved how there was so much of it.  I normally don't like vinegary BBQ sauces, but this one grew on me and I actually surprised myself by dipping my fries in what was left at the end.  All in all, it came out to $17 before tip...not bad at all!    

Nice little patio area in the back too...I could totally see coming back to hang outside with friends on a sunny day.  I also loved the red walls and the cool skull art on the walls.  I was told that they have already sold some of the art and that they were having an (art) opening next week.  Red walls and skulls...LOL...it felt like home! :) 

The uni-sex bathroom had a nice tall mirror in it which I thought was kinda flattering...it gave me the impression that it makes one look a little thinner than they really are.  Definitely a good thing.

Extensive list of beers on the wall (including the ubiquitous PBR) and I was happy to see that they had a variety of wines up on the board as well.  Looking forward to coming back soon to try those sliders (fried chicken, beef, lamb, or BLT!)  This place turned my day around...at least until my transmission self-destructed although that's another story...as a result, couldn't make it to Comstock either.

Nice feel to the place and a lot of locals and regulars are coming in during the daytime.  In barely two weeks it already feels quite established and I have a feeling this place will be around for a long time.  Cute place...not sure what it's like at night, but looking forward to finding out.
author: Roy N.

description:
It's one of those rare, magical San Francisco nights that feels like a Tennesse Williams play; warm and balmy, the smell of jasmine blooming, and if you listen real hard you can hear the cicadas chirp. Okay not the latter, maybe just your local tranny crack hooker yelling at her pimp. No matter, but anyone who has survived our bleak nuclear summers will know that the return of our friend the high-pressure system means fog-free days and warm nights where you can dine al fresco without the need for a sweater. Yet due to our Arctic summer weather, those places are few and far between.aside from getting abused at Zeitgeist or risk douchebag exposure at Medjool.

The Sycamore is a diamond in the rough that is Mission Street,  small, dark, with interesting artwork and on a warm summer night will transport you to Brooklyn. A small, neighborhood bar with a patio outside, great jukebox selection, good food, and decent drafts on tap. When my friend's beer was the last pour of the tap, the bartender comped it. That's Brooklyn for ya!
author: Suzanne R.

description:
I would definitely come back.
This is the kind of place that is good for a few friends, conversation, and laid back food and beer.

I liked the fries, lamb sliders, and butter lettuce salad best.  The cod and beef sliders were ok.  The cod had a really light skin of fried batter (perfect!) but didn't have any taste to it.  Maybe if I had put salt, or some sauce on it, it would be amazing.
The pulled pork sandwich was also just ok - would have been amazing if they put pickles on it, and used a sturdier bun.

That said, good music, good vibe, pretty cheap (2 sliders + fries for $7!)
author: J. F.

description: Good selection of craft beer, good bar food to go with it, with a cozy atmosphere.
author: Cris R.

description:
I went to The Sycamore yesterday to kick off the Cinco de Mayo festivities and I was a fast fan.

The people who work here are friendly. They take credit cards. There is a great back patio that lacks the pretension of other great patios in this area. And THE FOOD! The roast beef sandwich lived up to its reputation....the meat was tender and the bread they use is heavenly. I also had some of the pulled-pork sandwich which was also very tasty.

I tried the pork belly donuts which everyone else loved but I think they might have been a little too hardcore for me. I can't wait to come back here for Sunday brunch :)
author: Jackie M.

description:
Liz & Tim are kindly owners, and put a lot of love into this little place. It feels part European pub, part coffee house, and part jumping-off point. I absolutely love it. 

The chicken sliders are delightful, and the basket of fries disappear fast. My friend had the roast beef without the bun (due to her gluten allergy), and said it was just as fantastic standing alone. A note - the kitchen does close a few hours before the bar does, but that is perfectly reasonable. 

Great beers on tap, and carefully selected wines at good prices. This is my new favorite neighborhood pub.
author: Jill C.

description: Great sliders, great atmosphere, great trivia! I'd love to see a tasty salad on the menu!
author: Willow C.

description:
First of all, I love the atmosphere - it's got a bit of a divey feel, they have board games and I'm looking forward to checking out trivia night.

Now, for the food.  Sliders, mmmmmm...I had a fried chicken slider and lamb slider.  The fried chicken slider was wonderful!  I wasn't big on the lamb slider, but I think I just wasn't really in the mood for lamb meat.  I don't remember anything distinct about the fries, but they were fine.  I'll definitely be back to try more sliders and sandwiches.
author: Angela R.

description:
Looking for a slider (& a beer as a side)? This is the place to be!

Mix 'n' Match your sliders & add a salad or fries. Gotta love the Fried Chicken ones (though there's BLT, Lamb & Beef ones too)!

They've got trivia night & an outside patio!
author: Anna R.

description: This is the best place to have a Sunday Funday! Bottomless mimosas are $8 with food (and their food is great) and literally your drink is never empty! It is like they are mimosa ninjas lol! Plus they have a back patio that you can play card games, board games, etc. on. It's amazing.
author: Judie R.

description:
The Sycamore looks like a dive bar and has the drink prices of dive bar, but it's so much more than that! 

The food is good (I recommend the sliders and cobb salad) and it's a great hangout spot. I've always loved this place for it's good happy hour, yummy sliders on the dinner menu, cozy back patio, and board games. I've been there for early drinks and food before heading out in the Mission and late nightcaps, and it's always fun, rarely crazy crowded. Pretty easy to get food - just order and pay at the bar and they bring it to your table.

Didn't think I could like this place more until this weekend when I experienced their Sunday brunch! Best part: bottomless mimosas!! My glass was literally NEVER empty thanks to the roaming staff/bartender. I had the Veggie Benedict and it was one of my favorites in the city (includes kale, onions and peppers instead of canadian bacon). We also shared the pork belly donuts which are so rich and delicious. The back patio was sunny and nearly empty when our group arrived at 10:30, but was packed by 11:30.
author: Zoe F.

description:
I miss the hearty food of Cafe Prague that came before it (although not surprised they closed), but this is still excellent bar food with a fantastic beer selection.

While I wouldn't consider the pork belly donuts to be omgamazing, they're definitely refreshingly differnet and unique.

All of the sliders great, as were the roast beef sandwich, although the fries were just good.

Be careful though, they tend to have a heavy hand with the salt here.

Extremely affordable
author: Mark A.

description: I had a $4 draft and a basket of fresh hot crispy super delicious fries. There are picnic tables on back patio and it was a great place to chill over a couple a couple beers with friends.
author: Greg E.

description:
Very consistent and tasty, good quality food.  The sliders are excellent, particularly the chicken and fish.  We also have enjoyed the salads, mushrooms, and french fries, which are always fresh, piping hot, and delicious!

There is a nice selection of beers, and for those cold nights, they serve Hot Mulled Wine.  Mmmm.  

They can get crowded and loud at times, which loses them a star for a place to eat dinner.
author: Go S.
