description: The Sycamore is an awesome place. I've been here during the week and its a really cool vibe, chill yet fun. The most recent time I went was for brunch on a Saturday. He food was ok, I'd say like 3 1/2 stars but I've been here when it's not so busy and the food is very well made and very tasty. The ambiance, staff and overall vibe is definitely 4 stars. We also did he bottomless mimosas which they keep them flowin! Definitely a really cute spot in the Mission to check out.
author: Michi R.

description:
The pork belly donuts are succulent and lush, exactly what you expect from the name; they pair nicely with a Belgian wheat beer.  Meanwhile the lamb sliders - another favorite of the place - are fatty without any redeeming qualities; much resembling the Great Prosecution of the Christians, they are completely pointless.  
Overall 3 out 5!
author: Wa W.

description: Really chill bar with a good patio outback. Good place to grab a drink and kick back with friends. Dig the punk vibe and non-judgmental attitude.
author: Brad S.

description: The food is mediocre here. We tried the pork belly donuts, the chicken and bacon salad, chorizo eggs Benedict, and the smoked salmon eggs Benedict, and of course the unlimited MIMOSAS. Lets start with the good, the mimosas were regular orange juice and champagne but the waitress was ON her J.O.B. my glass was NEVER empty, and I mean NEVER kudos to that. The chicken and bacon salad, was on point too...I don't even think there was dressing on the salad, nonetheless 3 people can share this salad its quite tasty. The eggs Benedict's were O.K. and that's it, nothing spectacular, and nothing horrible, just O.K.  As for the pork belly donuts, I was excited to try them after reading all of the RAVE reviews, maybe I got a bad batch I don't know, the 'glaze" at the bottom of the bowl was the best thing, otherwise everything else tasted like bundles of fried dough with large crystals of salt melting down your throat, the pork belly was bland.  They also have various board games that you can play while you dine.
author: Michelle F.

description:
Oh what a quandry...I do want Sycamore to succeed because the owners are simply amazing, However, I don't want what could be my potentially new favorite hide away to get overrun by the wrong element (which likely means something completely different to me than it does to you!) Great menu; simple, succulent, delicious and affordable! Perfect selection of quality beers not only on tap but also by the bottle. Good wine selection, not extensive, but fully acceptable for a place that honestly doesn't seem to attract a huge wine crowd.
Then there's the big seller, the back area. Ah, on these lovely warm evenings it's a god send as well as a great place where your friends can smoke without disappearing on you - or having to deal with the crackheads on Mission while enjoying their cancer sticks.
I love this place, but SHHHHH....only tell the very best people about it!
author: Colleen B.

description:
This place is great. Great Juke box selection, beer selection and light bites. 

The artwork was dark and very much to my boyfriends liking. We ate the roast beef sammy and one each of the sliders, fried chicken, lamb, beef and BLT. The fries were good too. We also had the pork belly doughnuts, those tasted good but it was hard to get over the texture. That's just me though. All were reasonably priced.

The co-owner was cool and they seem to be getting along nice in the Mission. They really have it together for only being open for 4 weeks. 

We will definitely come back. This spot is casual and rocks.
author: Sarah D.

description:
I was impressed with Sycamore weeks before ever setting foot inside, after reading about their pork belly donuts with maker's mark maple glaze.  

We were greeted by a friendly bartender/server----you're supposed to order at the bar, but it was a little slow and so it was very nice of her to come over.  Yay for a nice selection of beers---tap, bottle, and can!

Of course we had to order the donuts.  They were divine---perfectly fried dough around a flavorful chunk of my favorite animal (to eat), topped with a sweet boozy drizzle.

Mister B and I both thought the fried provolone with chimichurri and roasted garlic was a great combo, though you need to have all three flavors for together in each bite for real balance.  I found myself wanting something to lighten the overall flavor up a little.

The butter lettuce with peaches and strawberries, goat cheese and chives with a tarragon vinaigrette was a perfect combo of creamy and tart, herbal and fruity.  

The fried chicken slider was good because just about any fried chicken is good, though again I wanted more acid (check out the sandwich with jalapeno coleslaw at Bakesale Betty's!!!).  Mister B really dug his spiced lamb slider, and we both thought the fries were aight.

I also fell in love with the eclectic and really cool selections on the jukebox.  To top it all off, our bill was super-cheap and we were stuffed to the gills.  

I can't wait to come back and play some music or hang out in the back patio on a sunny day.
author: Aimee B.

description:
I thought I would update as this place has been there for a while and settled in.  So far, I have eaten lots of dinners a few lunches and a couple of stellar brunches at the Sycamore.  I occasionally daydream about their fried chicken slider.  It is amazing.  What is even more amazing is that they make a fried chicken and gravy slider with a biscuit on the weekends!!  It is so  damn good I can eat it when I am not hungry.  The brunch dishes are a pile of food, so its hard to get sides like the chicken biscuit slider, but you really have to do it.  

The scene there is chill and welcoming, whether its busy or not.  I particularly like that their clientele is interesting and varied.  I have had some great conversation in the place.  It can be very loud, but I don't mind a loud bar, especially when the music selection on the jukebox is so cool.  I love the fact that they obviously picked all the music, so it really reflects the tastes of the people who work there.   

Oh, and a secret patio in the heart of the Mission.  If they served cocktails, I would probably never leave.
author: Liz R.

description:
their breakfast sliders are unforgettable. i had the fried chicken with gravy and the egg with sausage. both on biscuits! these sliders were the cutest sliders i've ever seen (picture speaks for itself). 

prices are decent, $3 a slider and $12 for bottomless mimosas. if you have an extra $3 to spend, try the pork belly donuts. pork isn't too flavorful but it's worth trying once.
author: elsie k.

description:
Cute.Cozy. very very small. Sliders/bar food etc. but great for a cozy little Mission night out, maybe great for a date ..why not..=)

Anyways, a group of us were there for just a drink b/c we realized it was too small for our group but i will be back here and give a review on their food. Atmosphere was like i mentioned above... some one came in here with their dog in the middle of the night ( i mean Sunday 8pmish) ..hmm..can u bring your dog here???.. .investigation on=)
author: C A.

description:
I have been here on multiple occasions now so I feel very confident in writing this review.

The Space:  Previously Cafe Prague, the new owners have almost completely gutted and redone the entire interior.  It is now very clean with a nice lounge/restaurant feel.  I love the aircraft carrier sized bar cause I can either stand or sit and feel comfortable.  The big bonus is the new outside patio area. 

The Drinks:  A great selection of beers on tap for almost anyone.  Thanks for the High Life.  A nice wine selection and the white sangria is a welcome change.

The Music:  One of the best damn jukes in the city, especially if you like good punk.

The Food:  By far the biggest draw for me.  The sliders are the first thing to draw your attention and they do not disappoint.  The beef slider with sauteed onions and blue cheese is insane but you can't go wrong with the BLT, Fried Chicken, or the Lamb Burger.  The Pulled Pork sandwich and the Famous Roast Beef

The Lowdown:  Come for lunch, come for happy hour, come for dinner...but get your ass to The Sycamore.
author: Dean H.

description:
On a Dive Bar Happy Hour committee? Check out The Sycamore. 

The bar is located in the Mission District on the corner of Mission Street and Sycamore Street (how aptly named, no?). 

There is limited seating - bench, chairs and stools. A small bar but lots of beverage options and a patio which would be great for the one week that it's hot in San Francisco. 

As for the menu, I preferred the lamb slider which has a nice amount of gaminess to it and the ground beef slider...the Point Reyes Blue Cheese makes this sandwich - each bite starts and ends with a rich and smooth creaminess. The pork belly donuts with maple maker's glaze (not shown on website's menu) actually has a cube of pork belly in it. Sweet, a bit of crunch, salty, and a bit of fat. It is not for the faint of heart. 

BONUS: They have a jukebox and a stack of gently used board games.

My friends and I had a fantastic time. We tried all the sliders and then order two more: lamb and beef, of course. Oh and I think we used an entire notepad playing Pictionary; we probably played through half the box of clue cards.
author: Cat T.

description:
Hell yeah, they have delicious sliders and a good selection of beers, including local microbrews. They take credit cards and have outdoor seating. So much to like!

I tried one of every slider and especially enjoyed the fried chicken and catfish sliders. Definitely had to order an extra round. I didn't get a chance to try the famous donuts but I heard they were pretty amazing.

I wish they had a full bar, but they do have a good beer selection and are happy to discuss the options with you. Service was good, prices are average. I'll be back.
author: Joseph N.

description:
I gotta say I love everything about this place. Except the famous pork belly donuts. Even to type this makes me nauseous.

I ate them last night and upon biting into the first one, got a pool of hot oil, which surprised me so much, I swallowed it. Ugh. I wish I'd done shots of olive oil instead. They were so oily, this surpasses greasy. I spent all night trying to keep them down. It's 12 hours later and I still feel sick. The pork belly was nearly raw- and evidently they think serving only the fat from the belly is appropriate. I ate them because I was with friends, distracted and laughing, and I bought into the hype about how good the donuts were. They were gross. I mostly blotted the other two doughballs dry and picked out the blubber inside, but the damage to my gut was wrought. 

I'm so disappointed because I wanted them to be good. I am still giving three stars for the service, the beer selection and prices. I had a great time, other than not sleeping and being epically nauseated for half a day hence.
author: Amani Ellen L.

description:
Damn tasty grub! Man, I didn't know what to expect walking in to this place which, at first glance, appears to be another hole-in-the-wall bar. However, I'm here to tell you, you haven't LIVED, till you've had a pork belly donut. Don't question, just eat it. 

This place has taken typical bar food to the next level with lamb sliders and delicious apps like the aforementioned donuts. Crispin Cider was also a plus. Love that stuff.

Service was efficient and witha  smile. Enjoy!
author: Robert M.

description:
I came to this place for lunch a few times. I usually get the mix and match sliders with greens on the side. I've had the Beer Battered Rock Cod, Ground Beef, and Fried Chicken--all very delicious. 

Sometimes I sit in the back during sunny days, but mostly I take it to-go since sunny means only a few days out of the year :)

The bartenders and staff were all very friendly everytime I went.
author: Jenn L.

description: Back patio, yummy brunch and mimosas so bottomless the glass never even reached half empty let alone the bottom.  I eventually had to cover my glass and wave the white flag when the waitress came around again.  We made friends with the table next to us and had great conversation.  There is smoking allowed outside, though we weren't sitting in a perpetual Parlament cloud by any means.
author: Monica S.

description: The tilapia sliders were fried, crunchy, and deliciously slathered in sauce. The beers were also plentiful. Definitely worth a visit if you're in for some great food in a grungy spot.
author: Isaac R.

description:
Great new pub / gourmet sliders joint in the mission. Funky / arty atmosphere with a good selection of microbrew pints and bottles. The sliders are awesome! The other reviewers are spot on...definitely try the lamb sliders....soooo delicious. Had a chance to sample the others...burger, fried chicken breast, and yes blt sliders! Just when you thought you couldn't improve a BLT sandwich, here comes the Sycamore with a BLT in miniature form.  At $3 a slider, just try them all! Cool outdoor patio in the back too.

Worth a visit! Just be careful with the neighborhood, this part of Mission street is dodgy at best. Got accosted by 2 not so friendly homeless people when leaving the pub.
author: Dave S.

description:
I'm giving the Sycamore 5 stars for their BEYOND DIVINE mushroom/crostini appetizer (seriously--incredibly yummy and healthy), and their perfectly tender and scrumptuos and delicious and well-priced lamb sliders/burgers, plus their rockin' jukebox/music and ambiance (which made it seem like we were at a party) in a fun location on Mission (down the alley from the Elbo Room).

I thought their french fries were okay (but my friends really loved 'em), and it was fairly crowded with a hip but non-pretentious seemingly local crowd, which meant that there was a constant line for their one bathroom... If this new place gets as happenin' as it should, they should invest in a second bathroom :).

The patio area was a nice surprise, too, reminding me of a mini Foreign Cinema (but without the projector, but there were speakers for the jukebox music back there :).

I'm really looking forward to becoming a semi-regular at this place, especially if I get hooked on their lamb sliders...

Oh, note to the owner: the small candle holders might be a fire hazzard... I almost burned the paper that was in the bowl-thing that my sliders and salad came in...

Anyway, a great, satisfying, very yummy experience over all!
author: Ankur G.

description:
Came here on a Friday night prior to going out in the Mission.

"Pork Belly Donuts with Maple Makers Mark Glaze" - that in itself speaks volumes.  The crunchy, deep fried succulent pork belly with that glaze...drool.

They're sliders are great as well!  Nice selection on tap.  Will definitely try to come out for brunch sometime.
author: Tan T.

description:
I was looking for a casual, no fuss, quick (but still delicious) dinner last night and chose The Sycamore.

I ordered the roast beef sandwich. My friends ordered lamb, chicken, beef and catfish sliders with a side of fries. 

Everything was delicious (the fries were amazing) and was served up fast. I'd certainly go here again!
author: Lee D.

description:
Friendly crew, nice pub, delicious menu (the pan fried provolone is a must) and they're considering to include more veggie-gourmet options in it. Plus, they have games, including Yahtzee!

 - - Went back after a few months and it was somewhat different. The food wasn't so good (seitan sandwich kinda sloppy and the hamburger bun still doesn't help), the crew wasn't the same (or as friendly) and maybe it's now a place just for drinks (and I couldn't review this). At least Yahtzee was still there.
author: Elisa S.

description:
Came late night for some snacks and beers in january. 

Pork Belly Donuts - 5/5 holy crap holy crap holy these are good. Just further proof that bacon + anything = win. Seriously the ultimate equation of life. 

Pulled Pork: with Sweet and Spicy Barbeque Sauce and Pickled Slaw
 - 4/5 decent sandwich and filling. 

Now I really need to try them bottomless mimosas...

Only thing to consider is that they do close the kitchen comparatively early to when they close. The place is pretty small and dimly lit as well.
author: Ray J.

description: I really like this little spot. Small draft list but there's obviously some love been put into selecting these beers. They also have a bunch of games to play, I thought it was awesome to see a table of folks playing Operation. I didn't try the food, just stopped in for some drinks, so can't comment on the gastropub aspect of this place.
author: Stephen S.

description:
lamb sliders so killa... to make them make such a good and small meal all by it self... awesome...
killer beer selection constantly changing and good friendly service..
clean bathroom...
What more?  nive owners and a sister bar the willows! also good.
author: Adam O.

description:
great beer selection. cool outside patio. sliders, fries, pulled pork, and mushrooms made my dinner. the sliders were pretty delicious, had chicken and catfish.

the space is cool too. i'll be back on a nice saturday afternoon to drink and snack.
author: Ameer N.

description: It was my first time in San Fran and my girlfriend and I were on our way to Napa, so we decided to meet an old friend for lunch here. Everyone adored their food; I had the caprese salad (beautiful), my girlfriend loved her grilled cheese and roasted tomato soup, and my friend adored her fish and chips. Beer was wonderful, too. Yup, the cushions were a little dirty and there was that faint "dive bar" smell. For me, that kind of made it even better.
author: Tara R.

description: Who doesn't love a place that serves PORK BELLY DONUTS!!!  Come on....SOLD!  This place is a small lil corner bar in the Mission that was really popping when we showed up.  Luckily, we happen to find seating within the first 10 mins we were there.  I would of liked to sit out back but it was pretty packed in the back also.  Our group ordered the pork belly donuts which were amazing and I could ate those all night and sliders (fried chicken & beef) which were tasty too.  I had a glass of wine which was good.  I especially liked the dog sitting on a chair at the next table.
author: Natacha M.

description:
Of course we tried the Pork Belly Donuts and of course it was amazing. You really only need to eat one because it's so heavy.  When I split the last one donut with a friend...I almost wanted to rebuke pork belly. But it was definitely worth trying because they are oh so good. 

We also ordered a ground beef slider, lamb slider and the bread pudding.  I'm a huge fan of bread pudding but not theirs.  It was too soggy for me and I got tired of it really quickly. The sliders were good and the fries were better! 

Not overly impressed by Sycamore but it wasn't bad either. Will probably be back for mimosas.
author: Helen V.

description:
Came here for brunch. It looks really small inside but there's a back patio. Unfortunately it was a cold day so that kind of dampened the experience. 

Brunch menu wasn't too varied. I'm personally a fan of omelets but they didn't have any here so I tried the sliders here. Good, but nothing I'd go crazy for.

You have to order at the bar but they have great customer service - our mimosa glasses were rarely empty!
author: Srikanth K.

description:
I love this place! This has become my favorite bar in the neighborhood when I want a chill spot to grab a beer and a nibble. The staff is very nice and they get a good variety of patrons - hipsters and non-hipsters all welcome. The food options are somewhat limited but all delicious. All of the sliders I've tried have been excellent. 

When it's a sunny day (which is pretty rare nowadays), the patio in the back is a great place to enjoy the afternoon. I like that it gets crowded but not too crowded so that I can always get a seat when I want one. Definitely worth a visit if you're in the neighborhood!
author: Foodie K.

description:
Great prices on beer and food.  Fast service and nice ambiance.  Definitely worth checking out if you're in the area. 

Here's what I ordered:
fried chicken sliders
lamb burger slider
roast beef sandwhich

It was all good.
author: Elsa H.

description:
I've passed by this place a bunch of times but never stopped. The corner doesn't seem like the most hospitable of corners. But hey, I've been wrong before. 

The front/main room of The Sycamore is a lot more hip than I expected it to be. A fine mix of black and reds throughout the room make the artwork pop out of the wall. Most of the art is baed around black and whites with accents of cool metallics. The room had an "old fashioned" juke box. What that means is that it's one with buttons and no touch screen connected to an international database of popular top 40. Nope, I was listening to mostly indie pop. And I liked the change. I noted the board games sitting on a high shelf and the comfy booths lining the walls. 

The bartender was nice. She acknowledged me right away and excused herself to assist others before getting to me. I appreciate this compared to not getting noticed at all. Very respectful and knowledgeable about the beers.

Let's talk food. I had the pork belly doughnuts and it is great I didn't know what to expect, but I'm glad I got what I got. Imagine if you will a nicely braised, still very meaty, pork belly that's still got that luscious fattiness dripping from it. Now dip that in doughnut batter and fry it. Perfect drinking food. Forget a pulled pork sandwich, this is better.

Next up I had the pan fried provolone with chimichuri. A nice dish in and of itself. I wish there was some bread with the dish so that I wasn't picking up seared cheese. It was a surprisingly well seared piece of cheese, I'll give them that. But I'd like a little bread to round out the plate. Call me a sucker for the classics.

There's some other good looking stuff on the menu, but I haven't tried it yet. You can be assured that I will come back and try them.
author: Jay V.

description: we came here for a yc fellow kind of party.  its def better than a bar in financial district tho its funky smoky or whatever else.   yet its too busy with too many people and sometimes its hard to move around.  music is loud. food is ok.   but all together it gives out a good vibe.
author: Shuting Z.

description:
Love that they have dogfish head 90 minute on tap. Granted, it's a buck or two cheaper at Lucky 13 or Cassanova, but here you get to enjoy it while basking in the sun on their super chill back patio. After returning from work in the perpetual fogginess of the outer mission, I crave sunlight to any degree I can find it. I never understood why more mission bars don't have outside spaces.

Haven't tried the food, although it looks and smells super tasty.

The jukebox had some awesome tunes going and was chuck full of treasures that one doesn't normally find in your average music box.

Bartenders were super nice. Friendly, and suuuuuper chill. Yay!
author: Monica C.

description:
Just got back from lunch at the Sycamore...and I really like it.

Sliders:
Lamb - really juicy
Beef with Blue Cheese - perfect combo
Chicken - not enough friend chicken sammiches in town...very good.
BLT - Good

Fries?
Extra cripsy....seems like they may double fry them....very tasty.

Beer selection - very smart, features beers from unibroue (a brewery i totally dig)

In all, it's a very casual, beer and food joint...laid back...not too expensive. They made some changes to the back patio...it's shaping up nicely.

A welcome addition to the Mission lunch scene...
author: Jason M.

description:
This place is great. Awesome food, great rotating selections on tap, comfortable location. Family owned, local business. 

What else could you ask for?

DANK.
author: Stephen R.

description:
Sliders and beer is why we're here. As I learned one fine Sunday evening, the Sycamore is a bar that serves good food.

I arrived earlier than my friends, so I just ordered a Hoegarden (on tap) and read for a while. Very chill. After several minutes, my friends showed up and we ordered appetizers and sliders.

Overall, the food is quite good, but I'd have to say the appetizers are actually better. The fried provolone with chimichurri and garlic is a bit salty. Thankfully I love salt. The sauteed mushrooms provided a nice contrast.

Like I said earlier, the sliders are solid, too. The lamb slider with manchego cheese is pretty good, as is the ground beef with blue cheese. Truth be told, I told them to hold the blue cheese because I hate it.

I'd definitely come here again.
author: Huey K.

description: Its a fun place with decent food, good prices, and solid service.  Add the drinks and games on a weekend group brunch and its a winner.
author: jeremy d.

description: An extremely fun and dicey joint with ridiculous art on the wall.  No pretensions whatsoever, good short list of brews and their pork belly donuts was my initial siren call.  Not something I would go out of my way for but it has a fun and eclectic environment that I appreciate.
author: Jenn N.

description:
I really enjoyed an evening at Sycamore. First, they have a great selection of beers on tap. The kitchen is really where this place shines. The Lamb Sliders were amazing. I was skeptical about a pan fried provolone, however, they proved that it can be amazing, with roasted garlic. YUMM. 

I've been dreaming of a burger since I've left.
author: Alex T.

description: Very solid lunch place. I had the lamb and beef sliders, both tasty, as were the fries. Great beer selection and the back patio was inviting on a warm afternoon. Will return!
author: Valerie W.

description: After trying to get into the brunch place down the street with the absurdly long wait list, my friend and I were happy to sit down immediately at Sycamore. The bottomless mimosa brunch at Sycamore  truly is bottomless.... I honestly never did see the bottom of my glass! Order your food at the bar (I had two sliders-- one lamb, the other an egg sandwich-- and a side of fries). Very attentive and nice staff. The lady pouring the mimosas was great!!!! They had a shelf full of board games so maybe that's something fun to do while brunching. :)
author: Patricia M.

description: I was lured in by the creative pork belly donuts. They were  total let down. The meat needed more flavor. It was just fried fat and all I could taste was old fryer oil.
author: Jeanne C.

description: The Sycamore has great food and a solid beer and wine selection. Food here is good but not fantastic. Be sure to try the pork belly donuts at least once. They manage to be the perfect combination of sweet and salty. The place is crowed but manages to still feel intimate. A wonderful place to take a friend.
author: Aaron W.

description:
The pork belly donuts with Maker's Mark glaze is an appetizer must. At $3 for three of the fried doughy, greasy, salty, sweet treats, you should consider ordering two orders. 

Lots of beer options and a relaxed atmosphere complete with board games. 

I'm always happy to see a place that includes Sriacha in its condiment offerings.
author: Lee H.

description:
This was our second visit for Brunch. The food was very bland! No seasoning at all. Probably the worst biscuits and gravy I have ever had. Dry biscuits on the sliders as well.
No salt and pepper on the tables.
You also have to go up to the bar (very crowded) to place your food order.
We won't be back.
author: scott c.

description: Love the outdoor patio area, movies playing on the wall at night. Hope to make it back for food soon.
author: Nicole S.

description: Food portions might be small for some but that aside its great tasting and bottomless mimosas! Friendly staff as well. Watch your head when walking to the patio area . Also people smoking in the patio could ruin your brunch experience (if you are not a cigarette smoker). Things to try are : the pork belly donuts, pulled pork sandwich, the chicken biscuit breakfast sandwich.
author: Wei W.

description:
Yelpers to the rescue, again!  We were looking for a place to grab a quick bite, and this bar turned up.   It seems to be a hipster hangout/bar, but don't let that dissuade you - they have amazing food. 

 More specifically, pork belly donuts!  I heard another patron call them "pork pieces of heaven", and he's exactly right.   Crispy but not too breaded batter covering soft & tasty pork, with just the right amount of maple glaze... Mmm, seriously, if you aren't drooling already, I don't know what's wrong with you.  

Will have to come back just to have the donuts again, hopefully we'll make it in time for bottomless mimosas ($12) next time!
author: Joyce H.

description: Came here for brunch on a Sunday with a few friends. It's a little bit of a madhouse when you first come in since there's no waiting list or anything for a table, but soon you figure out that you just need to make a few friends and you'll be sitting in a few minutes. I have to say, the mimosas were delish...I dunno what kind of OJ they were using but they were divine. Not too intense, but definitely got the job done. I think it was $12 for bottomless with an $8 food purchase. I got a couple sliders and a fruit cup for my food. I loved the lamb slider but the fried egg and sausage one was just ok. FYI, you have to order at the bar so don't wait around at the table, haha. Our server was always on top of it with the mimosas and we loved how they had games for us to play. Boggle ftw!
author: Leslie C.

description: Came in for the food and a beer, but nothing caught my eye.  The bartender was not very enthusiastic and did not really try to sell us anything. The place looked a little dirty, so we just had one beer and left.  I was still wondering what the high ratings were all about.  We went three blocks away and had a five star experience at another place.
author: Jason B.

description:
We stopped by The Sycamore for dinner on Friday to kick off SF Beer Week because we'd heard they were doing food & beer pairings.  It turns out the pairings aren't starting til next week, but there was still a pretty decent selection of tasty beers, plus a one-page menu of reasonably-priced pub-style offerings (fries, marinated olives, sauteed mushrooms, salads, sliders, pulled pork sandwich, etc.).  The butter lettuce salad with pear, strawberry, & goat cheese was excellent, the lamb sliders were darn tasty, & I quite enjoyed the pulled pork sandwich (which included a ridiculous quantity of pork; my bf didn't care for the sauce, but I thought it was fine).

The place is small & the atmosphere is a bit divey, but the bartenders/servers were incredibly friendly, helpful, & knowledgeable.  We ate at the bar (though they have a patio out back for nice weather) & quite enjoyed our meal there. :)
author: Angela B.

description:
Had lunch here with Kevin yesterday and it was great. I had a beer and the pulled pork sandwich w/fries. The fries were terrific. The sandwich was very good, but not completely traditional. 

Kevin had a delicious cobb salad. 

GREAT SPOT!
author: Art A.

description:
YES. DO ITTTTT. A solid gastropub. And by solid, I mean solid gold.

Seating was a bit hard, but when we got our food... I didn't even care.

While the seasonal mushrooms appetizer sealed the deal for me, the ridiculously delicious should-not-exist sangria took it over the top.

I think these guys are relatively new - saw some of the staff putting up decor still and experimenting with where to put it. 

This is a must do in the Mission.
author: Izzy P.

description:
Every time they change the beers, my heart is briefly broken
As tiny whimpers leave my lips the magic words are spoken
"Have you tried this? Not the same, but malty, smooth and light,"
And with that sip, that fateful sip, all wrong has been turned right.
author: Annelise D.

description: The sliders were so delicious. The fries and salad $1 each. So good. Not for the parents due to the gritty environs. But delicious!
author: Andrew K.

description:
Fantastic rotating draft beer selection.

The pork belly donuts are divine.

Every slider is incredible.

The only thing that's not top notch: the greens. It's a small mound of baby greens swimming in oil. I don't expect a place with amazing beer and pub food to be good at salad, so I'm still giving this place 5 stars.
author: Ross A.

description: A cozy hipster bar in the mission. Not much seating inside near the bar but they have a patio in the back with picnic tables.  They offer several beers on tap and have a good selection of bar food and delicious sandwiches. I loved their Goose Island Matilda Belgian. The staff were friendly and outgoing.
author: Alfred L.

description:
Pretty cool spot.  Good beer selection, nice variety, reasonable prices, chill vibe, small intimate space.

The enclosed outdoor bench area is a nice surprise and a perfect spot to kick it with some conversation.

I will return.
author: Chris J.

description: Great service! Came here on a Sunday and got endless mimosas and got my glass refilled before I could ask to get a refill.
author: Stacy H.

description: A no nonsense place to get a beer and something to eat. Want some water? It's on the counter. Want a coffee? It's on the counter.
author: Erich V.

description: The Sycamore is awesome! One of the coolest bars/restaurants. It's so under-the-radar and great for a casual meal in San Francisco. The bottomless mimosa deal is amazing. And the board games! Love it. Going back soon!
author: Jessica S.

description: This has to be my favorite spot in SF. Its small, has outdoor seating and amazing service. Bottomless mimosas are a must! Kim will never let you see the bottom of your glass and will hang out with you after her shift :) the food is amazing. I would recomment the eggs benedict with the jalapeno hollandaise mmm! Great atmosphere! You wont be disappointed.
author: Avery M.

description:
New favorite! We'll definitely become regulars soon enough, especially now that Monk's Kettle has doubled their prices and shrunken their portions. But I digress...
Had the super amazing mushroom appetizer, as well as the chicken slider and the fish slider. Not my most shining moment as far as healthy food goes, but it was all very delicious and I didn't regret it (for too long anyway) 
The delicious Poppy Jasper was on tap, and their entire beer selection rotates frequently. 
Love the ambiance too, felt warm and cozy and just punk enough. Tonight is their first quiz night, so will have to check that out sometime!
author: Lisa Marie G.

description: With just a single bartender behind the bar and a big crowd, the bartenders handle it so well. Yea, you have to wait in line, but that's life. Especially on Wednesday's BINGO night and Sunday's Bottomless mimosas afternoon, everyone who works there tries so hard to make the patrons happy and content. The food is great (kudos to the cooks!), the bartenders are amazing, and I have a great time at The Sycamore every time I go.
author: Zane L.

description:
This place is awesome.  You don't often see Pork Belly Donuts with Maple Marker's Mark Glaze on a menu, and when you do you order it.  And I did.  And it was amazing.  Highly recommended.

The sliders were a mixed bag.  The Fried Chicken slider was pretty good, and the Ground Beef slider was fairly unremarkable.  The Lamb sliders were the clear stand-outs; something very special is happening with that lamb.  

The fries are worth mentioning as well, as they were perfectly crispy and quite tasty.  The beer selection was small (about 8 on tap?) but quality.

Overall this place is great.  It's completely unpretentious, fairly cheap, has a nice beer garden out back for sunny days, and lots of board games for those who enjoy such things.  Service was friendly and prompt.  And they're open during that 2pm to 6pm time range when it seems every other decent place in the Mission is closed.

Oh yeah, don't order a salad here.  If you want a salad go someplace else.  That's not what this place is for.
author: Jorf D.

description:
I'm always in search of a place for a bar that offers good yet affordable food - not just pub food, in a warm cozy conversation friendly environment. The Sycamore is the place!

Great little bar with a good list of beers and wines, plus fabulously delicious sliders! Many less common beers available plus a few cheaper options. Bartender/owner is very friendly and laid back. Sliders are very tasty and come in beef, chicken, lamb and other meats.

Place is open for brunch on weekends and serves the sliders plus salads and other entrees.

Bonus: jukebox is a great collection of 80s, 90s, and more recent stuff that didn't make it to the Top 40.
author: Brian S.

description: Came here on a Tuesday night looking for a chill place to drink a beer and eat some decent bar food with an out-of-town friend.  The Sycamore was perfect!  I got a random combination of food - pork belly donuts followed by a bbq seitan sandwich, and both were really good!  That's a good sign, no?
author: Shauna L.

description: Came here for brunch because radish one of my favorite brunch spots in the mission for bottomless mimosas was packed to capacity. .. so I came here.  Wow terrible food I got the sycamore chicken waffles, man was it bad the chicken was like some sort of frozen Tysons chicken tender things and the waffle felt l was chewing bricks I mean I had to struggle swallowing them.  Now then, on to the service, service was friendly but could have been much more attentive. Basically had to walk up to the bar to place my order, then sat for ten to fifteen minutes waiting on a refill of my mimosa while all the staff gathered at the bar cracking jokes. Finally I got up again walked to the bar and refilled it myself. Ashame since this place has literally five tables total, two of which the only ones occupied. Bottom line if you come here I'd recommend do so only for the mimosas otherwise you can waste money on burnt ego waffles and frozen chicken tender suprises. You really do get what you pay for foods cheap and it reflects in the taste.
author: Johnny M.

description:
Some may be surprised at the 3 star mark but it's largely because the group I was with that night was not looking to go for a bar experience so we did take-out. So my review is strictly regarding their food and not their beer or atmosphere, though the bartender was a pretty cool guy. 

Those pork belly donuts were overrated I'm afraid. It's simply a piece of pork belly, albeit a good piece, wrapped in dough and fried. Sure you have the syrup on the side but it seriously needs to be soaked in it to live up to the 'donut' name. I came in with the idea that it would be like a donut donut, not fried bread. 

Yes, the sliders are pretty awesome. The lamb was excellent, the chicken was excellent, the beef was excellent, but the fish was only OK as it was more batter than fish.

Biting into the roast beef sandwich the first thought I had was that it reminded me of a hamburger in sliced beef form. It was probably the sauce but the sandwich was pretty tasty and if it was a hamburger it would make a good hamburger. 

So The Sycamore has some great food and I may decide to go again some day for lunch or at night with a different group. I do think this place is worth a visit.
author: Kat W.

description:
This was such a sexy meal.  
The food was amazing - fried provolone??  Oh my goodness, it was like Christmas morning.  
We tried one of each slider, the BLT was the favorite.  The chicken came a close second.  We also had both the pulled pork and the roast beef sandwich (yea, we were hungry).  
Overall, super impressed.  
I didn't even mind that I could barely walk on their crazy ass floor without tripping and falling (try not to be drunk and walk in there, because you will die.)
Plus they have board games!  How precious is that!
author: Rachelle P.

description: Hey, if I've been waiting to give my order for 5 fking minutes and you say "7 o'clock, happy hour is over," I say "this place sucks!"
author: Peter O.

description:
Poppy ate SO much here!  

Sliders were very tasty, I had every single one, BLT, lamb, chicken and the burger with blue cheese...but the very best sandwich was the Sycamore's famous with sauce.   It's like an Arby's roast beef (which is a compliment, I adore Arby's!) but better.  I wish I could have eaten two.  Fries are best, salad was boring.

Many very cute music nerds by the bar.  I've mentioned this to some of my girlfriends who are into alabaster mission guys with good hair.

Will be back again soon!
author: Poppy C.

description: The staff is always nice, the beer is always good and on rotation, good prices, great food, and a really chill outdoor patio.  The brunch on the weekends is great too with bottomless mimosas.
author: Jacob A.

description: Cool, small bar on Mission with a hidden back patio that is nice for relaxing, chatting and drinking a beer on a weeknight.
author: Diana H.

description:
Let me tell you that I am kinda cheap when it comes to giving stars but this place deserves 6 stars!!!
THEY ROCK! we went on a beautiful day and they have a great outdoor patio awesome ****
*** also for the food that is so creative even for breakfast and really yummy!!!
super ***** to the bottomless mimosas and even more **** to the waitress who never gave us the hint that it was time to leave even after we had finished our food but quite the contrary kept on refilling our glasses. We asked for a pitcher even during the meal  and got one (we were only two)
The lushes will be back
author: Carpe D.

description: The pork belly donuts are amazing! Great breakfasts! Fun atmosphere.
author: Stephen B.

description: The San Francisco bar scene hardly excites me. Every one seems to cater to one sort of folk. Hipsters, come here. We have $2 PBRs. Douche bags, this your spot. Ruffies are on the house. Hippies, hello! Have a shot of tequila with your shot of wheat grass. But where do all the people who suffer from identity crisis go? To the Sycamore, I say. It's a little divey. Has a solid beer selection. A perfectly sized patio. One tiny unisex bathroom. One tiny bar. And all sorts of people from snobby sorority looking gals to dudes who can't be bothered to pull a comb across their head. Plus, Dog Fish Head on top. Need I say any more?
author: Alexis M.

description:
Tasty beers! Tasty sliders, fries, gastro-food! Cozy atmosphere--with boardgames, always a plus! Jukebox with good selection! Very nice, patient bartender! Cool art on display! Back patio! 

Sycamore, I'm glad I've found you!
author: Sprout S.

description:
I'm a fan. 

Mmmm sliders. The lamb and fried chicken especially. Perfect amount of food and cheap! Cobb Salad is pretty awesome too. 

Love their beer selections (and bottomless junky mimosas on weekends). The owners are awesome. The brunches are fun. The atmosphere chill. Great jukebox to boot!

BONUS, back patio. Such a rarety in this city.
author: Natty C.

description:
Great pub food and unique beer selection. The sliders are a bite size of mouthwatering goodness and I can't bet over their fries-seasoned to perfection. I washed it down with a glass of Hoegaarden and a bottle of 
Maudite. 
The interiors are warm with red coated walls and friendly owners. They have a sizable outdoor back patio which is great for those occasional sunny days.

I can't wait to go back and try more amazing beer and that roast beef sandwich. I've salivating just thinking about it.
author: Rodel B.

description:
Hipster brunch. What is that you ask? Welll...... 

Found this place on yelp and I was immediately drawn to the chicken and waffles and pork belly donuts, so I grabbed my foodie sidekick and headed over to the Mission to search this place out. Like many restaurants in the Mission, it's pretty easy to pass, but if you go there once you'll remember how to get back. It's located on a corner between 17th and 18th and there's no sign in the front. We walk into the restaurant/bar and it's pretty tiny. As soon as I felt the vibe I looked over to my friend and she looks horrified. A lady who tends to be annoyed of the hipster trend she immediately questions my taste level. But I'm whatever as soon as I see sporadic food baskets at every table. Her expression was built by something other than the food though which were the games that were being played at every table and even the bar. I don't mind that thing, but it just goes to show the contrast of a all you can drink mimosas place in the Mission with a bunch of hipsters to the same deal in let's say the Castro of the infamous on going night club of Lime (RIP). We take seat at the bar and when her eyes fell on the menu she focused more on her goal and dropped her insecurities of the environment. 

I didn't really think to come on here to write about the food because it's pretty spot on with all the other reviews. Waffles stuffed with delicious surprise, soaked with syrup but maintaining crispyness and accompanied by a delicious three bite chicken tender. Crispy fries, delicious two bite lamb sliders, sweet, sticky fluffy donuts with salt flakes encasing tender pork and an overflowing fried egg with bacon slider. Okay, I guess it was worth mentioning. 

Glasses never got empty so it was hard to gauge how much I drank. The server told me if it never gets empty it always counts as one. I also tried a shot of this German liquor that I forgot the name of. It's 44% alcohol but it's served as a digestive.... Contains a lot of cloves but I liked it, and it was on the house :) 

In conclusion, I'm coming back, and my friend says that waffle is on the top 5 of the best things she's tried!
author: MaryAnn C.

description: It's been a loooong time since I've been to the Sycamore- and I need to go back. I mean come on, this place has Dogfish Head on tap! I've never eaten here (which is truly a shame), but I've enjoyed  a cocktail or two on their back patio. Anywhere in SF with a patio = Love.
author: Melissa N.

description:
Oh, so THAT'S what gastropub means. In other words, we didn't know this place was there, or that they served food, but we stumbled in from the rain, had no trouble getting seats and a really nice brunch for not much money, complete with great music & art on the walls. This place has a good vibe. 

There's nothing healthy on the menu, and basically no vegetarian options, so keep that in mind. 

But the food was really good. Anybody who can make a fried egg sandwich on a buttermilk biscuit, plain and simple, and not screw it up, is good in my book. Most places around here can't figure out how to make a biscuit that holds together, they're usually too cakey. Not so at this place! So relieved to know I finally got that biscuit location problem figured out. 

My only complaints are really minor: tap water could use a filter. Uh, yeah. Basically no complaints. Will definitely be back and hope it stays a secret hideaway for rainy days.
author: Sam Z.

description: Great place for a beer and a snack. Overly laid back, with great bartenders and a back patio. What more do you need?
author: Jeshua B.

description: I came in during lunchtime on a random Thursday. Nice and quiet, cute patio out back. The fried chicken slider I had was sooooo good! The tilapia was pretty good too. $3.50 each and you buy a la carte. Tons of beers, especially for a small spot. They have board games on a shelf, and an add for ladies night on Tuesdays which I might have to come back for! The staff wasn't super friendly but then here I was in business casual in a dive-ish bar (probably I looked way out of place!). Overall a great accidental find for lunch. I will absolutely come back.
author: Jessi T.

description: Super service and super food. I finally got to the menu and hells yeah. Pan Fried Provolone with Chimichurri and Roasted Garlic WHAT! So great. And, Housemade Seitan with Sweet and Spicy Barbeque Sauce and Pickled Slaw. Fantastic.
author: William R.

description: The pork belly donuts are to die for: partially out of ecstasy and partially from heart attack. All their sliders are equally delicious. Check out my detailed review at : http://www.operationpanda.com/2011/04/sycamore.html
author: DIanna l.

description:
Was here for a birthday party.
Great vibe, cute little Biergarten out back and some nice brew on tap.
I'll be back to try the food.
author: Anthony T.

description: Great food! all you can drink mimosas until 3 or 4pm! All of the bar tenders are awesome! They have board games, outside patio, and good vibes! This little gem is walking distance from BART which is perfect for consuming bottomless mimosas! This place fills up quickly on weekends so get there as early as you can.  Great for groups. The breakfast sliders are the perfect hangover cure, and the deep fried pork belly donuts are something you should try at least once.
author: Hannah J.

description:
What a great little spot. Better-than-your-average-bar-food bar food, well-thought out beer selection, great jukebox, friendly bartenders/owners - what more could I ask for? I had lamb, beef, and chicken sliders with fries, and all were quite tasty (especially the lamb!). I will be back to try some of their daily specials. Chili dog? Yes, please....

They've done a great job with a space that obviously has some challenges, and here's hoping they're only able to improve it more.
author: A M F.

description:
Last time I was in North Carolina, nobody wanted to drive an hour and a half to get "pork in a puppies - aka bbq pork stuffed hush puppies."

The Maple Donut Holes stuffd with pork belly at The Sycamore was a dream come true for me.

The beer selection was fantastic, and the cute guys next to me were eating the Burger and Pulled Pork Sandwhiches. Next time I'm getting the later after my donuts.

Nice Patio too!
author: Eric C.

description: Bottomless mimosas!...though I'm pretty sure we found the bottom. I left with an empty glass. I was so drunk by the time I got my food I don't have any strong memories about it...I ate all of it, which may be a good sign since I usually don't. The service was great (my platonic lady friend had a crush on her). If you like good deals and have no self control this is the place for you! Get there early
author: David S.

description: Came here on s Sunday for brunch.  Let's just say I should have known better than to order food from a bar.  Their brunch was greasy and bland, if I'm gonna be bad it better be good.  We ordered the chicken sliders and the pulled pork sandwich which tasted like it had been soaking in grease.  The only great thing was the bottomless mimosas.  Had it not been for their diligent efforts on never letting my glass go empty, I would have given only one star.  Not recommended for brunch.
author: Janelle D.

description:
Welcome to my first Yelp review. Big deal, right?

Got the Wednesday special, the classic and timeless Fish & Chips.

Definitely a nice atmosphere, located on 17th & Mission. Nice hipster waitress (the norm in the mission). Played both Connect 4 and Chess prior to food, win.

A staple in the Mission.
author: Patrick D.

description: This bar has everything going for it: an above average beer selection on tap, outdoor seating in the back, tasty food (ROAST BEEF SANDWICH!), friendly service, children, juke box, and even a wide selection board games!  I can see how the place can lose its charm when packed to the door with clientele, but The Sycamore is my kind of low-key bar stop.
author: Scott G.

description: After several visits, I'm adding The Sycamore to one of my new favorite hangouts in The Mission! The bar is small and tidy, so I prefer an early happy hour (4-7pm) arrival when tables are available. The beer and wine list is simplistic, yet very complimentary to their food menu! Find delicious and unique choices like Magic Hat No. 9 and Cherry Voodoo Tripel to go with your Lamb Burger or Fried Chicken Sliders! What I can't get enough of are their signature Pork Belly Donuts! Yes, Pork Belly Donuts- a tasty, fatty chunk of pork belly surrounded by a crunchy dough shell covered a with Maple Makers Mark glaze! Such a creative menu and I look forward to trying their brunches soon! Bring your coworkers or a date, grab a board game while you're there too, but make sure to get your hands on their Pork Belly Donuts!
author: Leroid D.

description:
Sunday Funday crew decided to branch out and hit up the Sycamore to begin our fantastic, much needed day in the Sun-day after about a week of rain.

Mimosas- $12 for bottomless and they are tasty.  You can taste the orange juice and be buzzin.

The notorious donuts- Delectable! But sir, may I please have some more...syrup!

Sliders- cant go wrong there.

I made the mistake of ordering the veggie omelete, forgetting I am not the biggest fan of goat cheese.  Too bad for the crew because I just mooched off of them.  

The space is small so if you don't want to work those muscles, get there early to grab a seat.  Awesome patio space too.
author: Elle B.

description:
LOVE this place! Have had great times here with some amazing people. The beer selection is impeccable and the food is unique compared to what you get at various other pubs yet maintains a great price point. Can't wait to go back! 

Also love the t-shirts and artwork that they display, definitely check it out.
author: Caitlin R.

description:
Go here for the great beer selection, cozy ambiance, nice little back patio, and the general entertainment that walks by on this stretch of Mission.  Food is just fine for a pub but nothing special

This is a great little neighborhood pub.  Good unique beer selection and a nice little menu.  This is not, however, a gastropub, unless gastropub is just a new longer way of saying pub.

In my mind, any place that has mixed bar and table seating and offers food but obviously considers itself a drinking establishment is a pub.  What makes a gastropub fit the category is that the food is better than your typical pub food (also that they might actually use plates and silverware).

I had Sycamore's "famous" roast beef sandwich and a Kolsch style beer whose brewery I didn't catch.  The beer was on draft and really tasty.  The sandwich came with their house made sauce.  The sandwich was decent, but we're only talking a step or two above an Arby's roast beef sandwich - same style too: round white bun, thin sliced medium grade roast beef, sauce and/or mayo.  No lettuce, tomato, onion, pickle etc.  Fries were really good.
author: Wes H.

description:
This place is one of the new wave of gastropubs that have hit the city - a little divey, a little rough around the edges, a concrete patio, warped wooden floors.  But where it might skimp a bit on decor, it focuses its attention on its surprisingly good food.

The menu is simple - a couple of starters and salads but the focus is the mini sliders (beef, lamb, fried chicken or BLT) and the sandwiches (roast beef, pulled pork).

Started off with some chili roasted peanuts, which were served hot.  Nice touch! And like the little kick of (spicy) heat as well.

The roast beef was delicious with tender meat piled on a soft bread that soaked up the hearty juices.  The accompanying large cut fries were crispy but soft on the inside (just the way I like them).

Also tried the ground beef slider.  Omg, three bites of heaven, especially with the healthy pile of point reyes blue cheese.  I also heard the BLT was good.

Love the unique beers on draft.  Had the rich Dog Fish Head 90 Minute IPA with its 9% alcohol content.
author: F. P.

description:
Wow, I do not get the love for this place. 

First, the food is horrible and overpriced--I had the cajun benedict and it was so bland and greasy. I only ate half of it, and I still walked around all day feeling like I had a rock in my stomach. 

the place is crowded-- hipsters streaming through the doors in droves to get cheap, bottomless mimosas and their fill of Old Maid and Yahtzee. The server actually told us when we came in that we would likely not ever get a table, and good luck. 

the bathrooms are disgusting--usually I don't call this out because, i get it, urban environment + high traffic area = gross. But these were beyond the pale. 

The service is the WORST--it took, literally, an hour to get our appetizer of pork belly donuts (which were also not good, by the way).

 the only plus side is that they're pretty good about making sure the bottomless mimosas constantly stay full.
author: Kathleen D.

description: Love the changing beer selection, the jukebox, the space, and the owners. Two thumbs up.
author: jml j.

description:
i'm almost afraid to even give a stellar review of this place simply because i don't want a swarm of other people to find out how awesome this place is.  one of the best things about it - no lines, no waiting lists, no fuss.

my friend and i came here for brunch on a random sunny saturday.  the people who work here are real nice, chill, down-to-earth peeps.  and the food is awesome.  no fuss, just good.  real good.  and the bottomless mimosas are pretty sweet too.
author: Diane D.

description:
Really just 3 stars.

The Sycamore has been on my list for a while. When a coworker mentioned that it served great sliders and beer - it was a no-brainer that I had to make my way over.

Today, my roommates and I checked it out. Findings below:

Ambiance: 
-Gritty and divey. The non-hipster Mission at it's finest.
-The Sycamore looks like it's been around for years - a small corner shop with a bar, some tables and a jukebox.
-Old tap handles line the ceiling above the bar. A fun touch a la Toronados. 

Food:
-We ordered the fries, pork belly donuts, salad, and sliders along with our beer.
-Fries: Mmm, medium at most. Similar to what I used to get at my high school cafeteria.
-Pork belly donuts: BEST PART OF THE MEAL. Biting into one of these was pork belly, succulent, heaven. Even better when dipped into some Ketchup and Tapatio. I'd come here just to order these with beer. No joke.
-Salad: Also ok. We ordered the caprese salad - which I was super excited about because it contained heirloom tomatoes. It ended up being mostly arugula which tasted a bit strange - more bitter than the spiciness I like arugula for. Additionally, I wasn't sure if the tomatoes were heirloom - but it sufficed.
-Sliders: Catfish, Fried Chicken, and BLT. Fried chicken was probably most delicious - a yummy chicken morsel - perfectly crispy on the outside and moist on the inside. Can't put my finger on what it was, but the sauce added a good kick! The Catfish was forgettable along with the BLT. Not enough flavor.
-Beer: Pretty good selection - refreshing with your sliders!

Good-to-Know:
-Order your food and beer at the bar. If you go with friends, have someone save a table.
-Mondays @ 8p are trivia night - and sometimes can also be on Wednesdays. This was a surprise to us when we visited today! Pretty fun quiz and not TOO hard. 
-Props to the owner being so enthusiastic and having a pretty challenging song round.

Eh, bet this place is fun for happy hour - which is, I think, from 4-7p. Def a local spot.
author: Gina L.

description: This is a hidden neighborhood gem. They have great selection of beer, friendly bartenders, and delicious food. The Sunday brunch is terrific, including the bottomless mimosas. The roast beef sandwiches are out of this world and comparable to kelly's famous roast beef from Boston. Also this place is reasonably priced. Overall a great spot that is highly recommended.
author: John F.

description: Yum! This place was small and delightful... Bottomless mimosas, pork belly donuts, and tasty egg scrambles.  seating is limited....
author: Sheila P.

description: I'm reticent to leave a review because I enjoy having a place to sit when I go there for brunch on Sundays... but the bottomless mimosas always mean I'll be taking a nap and the sliders and pork belly donuts are super tasty.
author: Tuffy M.

description: Great brunch spot; food is good for the price and they're typically so fast on the bottomless mimosa refills that you never see the bottom of your glass. There's a wide selection of board games to choose from; my group ended up playing apples to apples. There's enough space to accommodate a hearty number of people, but arriving before noon will ensure that you don't have to wait for a table.
author: Chris H.

description: mmmmm really tasty. I got the pulled pork sandwich which was delicious. Also a really good spot to hang in SF. Don't be shy to jump in on one of the long shared tables.
author: Rohan S.

description: Raspberry Wheat beer disaster!  I didn't experience the Sycamore at its fullest potential.  Instead I allowed myself to fall prey to the glamor of a seductive beer that tasted like my foot.  If my foot were made of moldy raspberries drenched in cigarettes and hops.  The joint was small and intimate.  I liked the stack of board games available.  The menu, which I didn't get to experience, seems inventive and tasty.  But damn, that beer was bad.  Why, bartender, did you let me give you money for that?  So I'm going to settle with three stars until I return.
author: Jeremy G.

description: Quaint a bit overpriced for the servings.  Overcooked benedict get it together
author: Shah S.

description: Interesting and tasty beers on tap, outdoor seating in the back, never too crowded (at least not anytime I've been there, including Friday nights), and deliciously crispy and salty fries.  Apparently they have pork belly donuts too.  I must say, I do so love this place, and so should you.
author: Jenn C.

description:
In addition to the new-friend-inducing patio picnic tables, high caliber pub  food, and Racer 5, they have quality human beings working behind the bar- they went out looking for me when I left my phone behind, remembering my name as they called down the street.
Up with people!
Up with the Sycamore!
author: Weste N.

description: Great roast beef sammie and super tasty fries. I loved the hoppy ale they recommended. $16 was the total bill. Make sure to check out the back patio.
author: Seghel Y.

description: I love this place! The staff is always friendly and the atmosphere is always inviting. Their food is excellent, from the brunch menu to dinner, it is always fast out of the kitchen and done perfectly. Their fries are always cooked to perfection and when they have special menu item it is creative and always tasty. Top of my list are the lamb sliders and the pulled pork is also a must try. Keep it up!
author: Jacob M.

description:
A great place to stop by, eat a bit, and chat with your friends.

This place is first and foremost a pub and bar, and one that encapsulates everything a Mission dive bar should have - a wide selection of drinks, an outdoor area in the back for days when the weather is generous, and the relaxation of an unpretentious place that knows it's good.

I came in starving and had three sliders (the norm): beer battered cod, lamb, and ground beef. I am the biggest fan of anything lamb but the cod was hands down the best. The fish was perfectly cooked with a crispy shell guarding a moist prize on the inside. Highly recommended for anyone who likes fish.

After eating, my friend and I sat around for an hour just to talk. I've noticed that highly rated Yelp places in the city often like to process as many customers as possible, but this place does not fall victim to its popularity or success. Instead, there are board games on the shelf in case you just want to hang around and enjoy the place.

I don't give five star reviews because that means perfection, but Sycamore has earned it.
author: Kevin S.

description:
The Potential: an awesome sunday brunch with friends, $12 bottomless mimosas to get a buzz before heading to work, and maybe a round or two of old school board games.

The Reality: We went in around 1:45, and got a seat for 6 after a 15 min wait (The only good part of this review). After ordering at the bar for some sliders, we all sat down and started sipping on our mimosas. 4 glasses and 50 minutes later, we still haven't gotten our food so we check on it with the girl behind the bar. She tells us its on its way, so we wait some more while she makes the rounds of mimosa refills while avoiding our gaze. Finally, 3 of the 4 plates show up... I went up and asked for my order again just as my friends all finished theirs. The egg on the fried egg slider was cold, the cheese not melted, and the fruit cup ($2 add-on) was a mess of tiny (fingertip sized) slices of melon and a few mushy blueberries. Also, I think they ran out of the regular bread for the sliders because we got the biscuits for all of them (chicken/egg/beef). She took my meal off the tab, but still really not worth it. By the time we were done it was 3:45 and I was being late for work. I'm really disappointed after reading all the awesome reviews here and wish my experience wasn't so bad.
author: Taiyo K.

description: The Sycamore is always my go-to place for meeting my team of electricians that go with me to Haiti.  It's close to BART, always has a great selection of beers on tap.  There are usually at least ten of us and for a seemingly small place the staff operates super efficiently.  And when your having good beer, all you need is good food.  The sliders are always fresh and flavorful.  We order twenty or so at a time of a variety from the menu.  Everyone enjoys every bite.  It looks small, but has a big heart.
author: Jeff R.

description:
I went in on Saturday evening with friends for a late dinner.  I had the sliders (beef, chicken and lamb) and they were awesome, especially the lamb.  My friends ordered the sliders (chicken, beef, blt), the seasoned mushrooms, and the barbecued seitan sandwich, plus everyone had fries.  Everything was a hit apart from the seitan which I believe was undercooked.

However, this didn't put a damper on anything as the atmosphere, the jukebox, the really awesome owners (Tim and Liz) and the great beer selection is what it was really all about.

If you're looking for a chill spot where you can chat with your friends, sink a few cold ones and not have to deal with drunk people spilling their beer on you, then this is it.
author: Prav P.

description:
- Interesting beer selection. Had a fantastic Belgian Tripel recommended to me by the helpful, friendly bar tender. 
- Tasty and cheap small plates (mostly sliders and fries). Sadly, they didn't have the cheese plate anymore (which you see on one of the menus posted here) though I hope they bring it back. 
- Little patio out back isn't exactly scenic but they did what they could with the area.
- The place was quiet and mostly empty when I first went on a Sunday afternoon. Late on Fri or Sat it gets packed and loud.
author: Kelly R.

description: I went for Sunday brunch.  Oh emmm geee...those pork belly donuts are so dericious it's ridicurous.  I swear, they just melted in your mouth.  The taste of salty pork belly with a light maple sweetness to it...yum!  I also enjoyed their biscuit breakfast sandmich.  The biscuit was smooth and buttery.
author: Tara K.

description: Food is awesome. Go there. Eat it. Be as hip as you think you are.
author: Wade C.

description:
This is a great new addition to the Mission bar and dining scene.  There is great bar and back patio with a wonderful selection of wines and beers, and a great juke box.

There were some standouts on the menu
- Amazing sliders, especially the fried chicken and the beef and blue cheese.
- Awesome roast beef sandwich in a soft role.

One of the other positives - they serve food from lunchtime onwards. I will definitely be back.
author: Carol O.

description: Mmmmm their salads and fried cheese is so yummy!!
author: cecilia k.

description:
This is by far my favorite bar in the Mission! It is run by super friendly people that pull in a really happy crowd, the sliders are amazing, and I think I've tried a new and exciting beer every time I come in. 

This is definitely my go to bar whenever I want to hang out with friends, I really like that it's not super loud so that you can actually talk to people, and the patio is awesome if the weather is nice out. There's always new artwork up on the walls, and the work they choose to display there is always really cool.

Plus extra stars for Scattergories, I had forgotten how amazing that game was until rediscovering it at the Sycamore. I hear that brunch with bottomless mimosas is also great, hitting that up has been on my to do list for ages and will hopefully happen soon!

Check this place out, you won't go home disappointed. You will go home full of delicious food and drinks!
author: Annelise P.

description: I came upon this gem of a gastropub on a recent Dishcrawl. It was a rainy night and the inside was packed with people so our group ended up on the back patio. Although there were covers up over the tables, the benches ere still quite wet. But we figured eh what the hell...there could be far worse things that having damp jeans so we took a seat. And proceeded to stuff our faces when the appetizers came out. Lamb sliders, beef sliders, and our beers were delicious. But the definite star of the entire evening was the pork belly donuts......whoa whoa whoa soooo delicious.  Even when we all stood up to leave, wet jeans sticking to our bums, we didn't even flinch or notice the discomfort. We just happily discussed coming back to the Sycamore to binge on some more amazing donuts...mmmmmm......
author: Colleen M.

description:
this review exists strictly for the pork belly doughnuts. 

full of win and deliciousness. eat them. 

other than that, we were only there for about 30 minutes: long enough to discover that i don't like their white sangria. 


pork. belly. doughnuts.
author: Brooke B.

description:
Friendly bartenders, great outside patio, and $4 drafts for happy hour. Oh and amazing pork belly doughnuts--- the sea salt on top is just right. 

I would recommend this Mission dive!
author: Rena Z.

description: Walked in here today for lunch on a very rainy day and thought, hmmm, this place doesn't strike me as having good food.  Well, I was dead wrong.  After settling into my bench, I started to feel the comfort of the place (friendly staff and crowd) and the warm chill started to come over me.  Had the cobb salad and it was delish - complete with bacon and fried chicken (I'm liking this new twist on cobbs -- salad/healthy, fried chicken/satisfying).  Art had the pulled pork sandwich.  He can't resist anything pull or pork.  I loved my bite.  And the fries.  A+.  Crispy and tastey.  I'll definitely be back to Sycamore!!
author: Kevin M.

description:
the pork belly donuts are so greasy that it hurt my stomach
the sliders are ok
the roast beef tastes like arby's. it was good
author: Christopher L.

description: Fast becoming one of my favorite places to go for happy hour (4-7pm).  They have a great selection of draft beers and also serve fantastic sliders!  The place is small but homey and an undiscovered gem in this area of the Mission so it's not tough finding a seat on a Thursday evening after work.  If you aren't sure between the four sliders selection, let me make it simple and say you should try one of each (my favorites are the lamb and fried cod) and add some fries to that for $1 while you're at it.
author: Ben T.

description: The Mix n Match Sliders are delicious especially alongside bottomless Mimosas for Sunday brunch, especially if its sunny and you can find a spot in the back patio.  They also have a nice selection of beer and a warm atmosphere.
author: Brian K.

description:
Lots to love about this place:
* great selection of beers (& wine)
* seriously YUM bar food menu that is small, but reasonably priced and excellent quality (sliders, mushroom crostini, cob salad are my faves ... and something about the way they do their fried chicken is magical - moist and crispy but not greasy)
* nice folks that work there - even when it gets crazy in there the bar ladies are super kind and patient
* outdoor area - a great SF secret because few places offer outdoor seating, drinks AND food 
* (this may change) but you can find a place to sit with your crew ... I'm too old to stand in a dark bar and have always found a seat out or in
* baby-friendly - our infant hung out all afternoon with our friends, I breastfed while sipping beer and no one made us feel like we were bad parents (I've also come with a stroller and hung out back)
* flexible - we hosted a drop-in kind of bday party there yesterday - the staff was super accommodating (we brought our own cupcakes; they juggled our multiple open tabs beautifully; they never seemed miffed when we had random requests for extra places, napkins, etc.), we were able to use 2 of the outdoor picnic tables for 5 hours or so and the owner even let us have an early happy hour off draught drinks (with prior arrangements); it was hard for our friends to find (can easily miss it between all the produce shops, and drug deals) but they all loved the place and will be returning again and again

We hope, unlike previous establishments at this site which never lasted, the Sycamore remains for a long, long time.  It's an awesome neighborhood hang and our new favorite, local place!
author: A H.

description: First off, this place is a dump. So to the  staff and owner; please don't change. It's got its own world once you walk through the half door, from it smell (not pleasant) to its vibe (organic.) It's thanks to these types of establishments cities can continue to offer an experience worth coming back too. Please don't come expecting a fancy and usual experience cause you won't find it here. Instead you'll find board games at the ready for any takers, a jukebox with great jams ready for listens, patio waiting for the smokers or the outside loving, and one bathroom. It's a joint that the mission district must be proud to call one it's own. I'm an outsider from Portland, OR so to me it reminded me a little of home, while I drank and ate there i struck up a conversation with 3 locals who not only loved the place but, also invited me to there next destination "Delores Park," which is a must visit for first time visitors. I came to this place for a beer and some food; left meeting 3 new good friends and making some great new memories.
author: Pablo P.

description: Went there for the first time for Carnaval 2014.  Had a great time.  The fried egg and sausage sandwich is great.  The bottomless mimosas even better.  Our mimosa Ninja never let the glass be empty.  Had a great time.  Will for sure go back.
author: Quincey S.

description: Outside patio. Check. Awesome bartenders. Check. Delicious morsels. Check. To die for beer on tap with requests for tastes being met enthusiastically. Check, Check. I want to come back for brunch ASAP, but the happy hour here is just what a gal is looking for on her way home from work....and maybe into the night, and then maybe back the next day. Well, you get the picture.
author: Shira O.

description: This is mos def my favorite local "go-to" bar. Outdoor patio is bonus for nice Indian summer days, bartenders are really awesome and friendly, different beers on tap depending on the day to switch it up, and definitely try the sliders! Good place to take a casual date as it doesn't get too loud so you can actually have a conversation, except for Monday night trivia night. Its a win win all the way around.
author: Jordan V.

description: Four stars for the laid back atmosphere and jukebox, perfect for a late lunch. And a nice beer selection. Three stars for the food- had a few different sliders, they were all decent, i actually liked the beef best. The pork belly donuts were a disappointment, not much flavor and weird texture.
author: Kristi B.

description: Love the Sycamore.  Cozy little neighborhood bar.  Staff is always friendly.  The patio out back is great.  This place gets pretty busy (as it should) so hopefully you can find a spot when you arrive.
author: Sarah G.

description:
AMAZING BEERS!!!  This is the place for happy hour, day drinking, morning drinking etc etc

The owners are awesome, the atmosphere is super chill and the patio seating just seals the deal

PS their sliders rock too!!
author: Bradley S.

description:
small bar setting, very cute. very mission. great music and art work.

the sliders were amazing!! i had the beer battered rock cod and lamb, my friend got the cod and chicken. all delish. we also had an order of the pork belly donuts (3 for $3). totally worth it. 

the albino python was a really great ginger spiced beer. also recommend the mould wine... 

my only complaint (and it wasn't a big deal) was the fruit flies that kept coming around.
author: Jen C.

description: HOT BEEFS! HOT BEEFS! HOT BEEFS! and a great patio! you can also order their food for takeaway, which is excellent when suffering a hangover.
author: Kristin J.

description: We ate a bunch of sliders: fried chicken, lamb with cheese, beef. They were fine. Good beer. Good jukebox. Woman at the counter was extremely nice. Solid but not super exciting.
author: Little M.

description: I was kinda of underwhelmed with the pork belly donuts. When I first heard about them, I was instantly intrigued. I was quite excited to try them but they were good but nothing extraordinary. The description was definitely better than they tasted. Maybe I am picky but cold pork belly isn't that appealing. When I have had pork belly in the past, it always melted in my mouth and I was kinda of expecting that when I bit into this donut, the fat from the pork belly would just melt and coat my mouth. The first bit was alright, the syrup was definitely a nice complement but the pork belly just wasn't hot enough...I know it's fatty but biting into a lukewarm piece of pork fat just isn't that great. The roast beef sandwich was tender and the bread was nice and soft. The food here is good but I would say the description plays up the food. The service here is excellent and they all make sure you are taken care of. There is a huge selection of beers.
author: Eve C.

description:
Seriously dont go here! NO.... just kidding.... I just dont want it to get so crowded that I cant get a seat. I love this place! I have been a few times and the food is consistently great. You can sit inside and play board games or outside in the backyard at the picnic benches. They have endless mimosas as well as a full bar for other treats like bloody mary's. The only drawback on the bloody is it had no veggies in it- which is my favorite part. 
It feels like a mini zeitgeist but minus the crowds and asshole bartenders. The food is also WAY better and CHEAP! 
Sliders are $3 and you can get sides of fries or potatoes or fruit for a few bucks.  Everyone who works there is super duper nice. 
I highly recommend the pork belly donuts and sliders. All of them are so good! The fried chicken slider comes on a hot biscuit with country gravy dripping off it. The lamb burger is also seasoned perfectly. I have never had something so sinful as the pork donut with sea salt and whisky glaze. It is an orgasm in your mouth. 
Be warned, its all comfort food so be prepared to take a nap immediately after eating.
author: M K.

description: Read the great reviews on Yelp and decided to check this place out after work one night last week.  Decor is a typical neighborhood dive bar, but their lamb and their chicken sliders were out of this world.  The beef slider was good, but not nearly as good as the other two.
